tumor of abdomen (disorder)	New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
non-haematological tumours of unspecified malignancy (smq)	Malignancies (SMQ) includes terms for: all types of malignant or unspecified tumors; malignancy related conditions; malignancy related therapeutic and diagnostic procedures; and tumour markers. [Note: Premalignant disorders are in a separate SMQ]. There are ten sub-SMQs which can be used separately or in combination. Malignancies (SMQ) is subdivided into four sub-SMQs: Malignant or unspecified tumours (SMQ); Malignancy related conditions (SMQ); Malignancy related therapeutic and diagnostic procedures (SMQ); and Tumour markers (SMQ). Malignant or unspecified tumours (SMQ) contains all MedDRA terms for malignant or unspecified tumors, which is further subdivided into two separate sub-SMQs: Malignant tumours (SMQ); and Tumours of unspecified malignancy (SMQ). Malignant tumours (SMQ) is subordinated by Haematological malignant tumours (SMQ); and Non-haematological malignant tumours (SMQ). Tumours of unspecified malignancy (SMQ) is subordinated by Haematological tumours of unspecified malignancy (SMQ); and Non-haematological tumours of unspecified malignancy (SMQ).
non-hematological tumors of unspecified malignancy (smq)	Malignancies (SMQ) includes terms for: all types of malignant or unspecified tumors; malignancy related conditions; malignancy related therapeutic and diagnostic procedures; and tumour markers. [Note: Premalignant disorders are in a separate SMQ]. There are ten sub-SMQs which can be used separately or in combination. Malignancies (SMQ) is subdivided into four sub-SMQs: Malignant or unspecified tumours (SMQ); Malignancy related conditions (SMQ); Malignancy related therapeutic and diagnostic procedures (SMQ); and Tumour markers (SMQ). Malignant or unspecified tumours (SMQ) contains all MedDRA terms for malignant or unspecified tumors, which is further subdivided into two separate sub-SMQs: Malignant tumours (SMQ); and Tumours of unspecified malignancy (SMQ). Malignant tumours (SMQ) is subordinated by Haematological malignant tumours (SMQ); and Non-haematological malignant tumours (SMQ). Tumours of unspecified malignancy (SMQ) is subordinated by Haematological tumours of unspecified malignancy (SMQ); and Non-haematological tumours of unspecified malignancy (SMQ).
tumor abdominal	New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
abdominal neoplasm	New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
abdomen tumours	New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
neoplastic growth	New abnormal growth of tissue. Malignant neoplasms show a greater degree of anaplasia and have the properties of invasion and metastasis, compared to benign neoplasms.
neoplastic process	The pathological mechanisms and forms taken by tissue during degeneration into a neoplasm and its subsequent activity.
abdomen tumors	New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
neoplasm, nos	New abnormal growth of tissue. Malignant neoplasms show a greater degree of anaplasia and have the properties of invasion and metastasis, compared to benign neoplasms.
neoplastic process (qualifier value)	The pathological mechanisms and forms taken by tissue during degeneration into a neoplasm and its subsequent activity.
abdominal neopl	New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
neoplasm of abdomen (disorder)	New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
abdominal tumours	New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
tumour of abdomen	New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
abdomen--tumors	New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
neoplasm of abdomen	New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
abdominal neoplasms	New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
abdominal tumors	New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
abdominals tumors	New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
tumor abdomen	New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
abdominal tumour	New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
abdominal neoplasm nos	New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
neoplasm of anus	Tumors or cancer of the ANAL CANAL.
neopl biliary tract	Tumors or cancer in the BILIARY TRACT including the BILE DUCTS and the GALLBLADDER.
tumor of bladder	new abnormal urinary bladder tissue that grows by excessive cellular division and proliferation more rapidly than normal and continues to grow after the stimuli that initiated the new growth cease.
neoplasm, abdominal	New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
ngb - new growth of bladder	new abnormal urinary bladder tissue that grows by excessive cellular division and proliferation more rapidly than normal and continues to grow after the stimuli that initiated the new growth cease.
neoplasm of the uterine cervix	new abnormal cervical tissue that grows by excessive cellular division and proliferation more rapidly than normal and continues to grow after the stimuli that initiated the new growth cease.
mole, invasive	A uterine tumor derived from persistent gestational TROPHOBLASTS, most likely after a molar pregnancy (HYDATIDIFORM MOLE). Invasive hyadatiform mole develops in about 15% of patients after evacuation of a complete mole and less frequently after other types of gestation. It may perforate the MYOMETRIUM and erode uterine vessels causing hemorrhage.
neoplasm of endometrium	Tumors or cancer of ENDOMETRIUM, the mucous lining of the UTERUS. These neoplasms can be benign or malignant. Their classification and grading are based on the various cell types and the percent of undifferentiated cells.
fallopian tube tumor	Benign or malignant neoplasms of the FALLOPIAN TUBES. They are uncommon. If they develop, they may be located in the wall or within the lumen as a growth attached to the wall by a stalk.
neoplasm of intestinal tract	Tumors or cancer of the INTESTINES.
neoplasm of intestine	Tumors or cancer of the INTESTINES.
pancreatic neoplasms	Tumors or cancer of the PANCREAS. Depending on the types of ISLET CELLS present in the tumors, various hormones can be secreted: GLUCAGON from PANCREATIC ALPHA CELLS; INSULIN from PANCREATIC BETA CELLS; and SOMATOSTATIN from the SOMATOSTATIN-SECRETING CELLS. Most are malignant except the insulin-producing tumors (INSULINOMA).
pelvis tumors	Tumors or cancer of the pelvic region.
abdominal wall neoplasm nos	Tumors or cancer of the PERITONEUM.
prostate tumor	Tumors or cancer of the PROSTATE.
neoplasm of the retroperitoneum (disorder)	New abnormal growth of tissue in the RETROPERITONEAL SPACE.
ureteral neoplasm	Cancer or tumors of the URETER which may cause obstruction leading to hydroureter, HYDRONEPHROSIS, and PYELONEPHRITIS. HEMATURIA is a common symptom.
neoplasms, urethra	Cancer or tumors of the URETHRA. Benign epithelial tumors of the urethra usually consist of squamous and transitional cells. Primary urethral carcinomas are rare and typically of squamous cells. Urethral carcinoma is the only urological malignancy that is more common in females than in males.
uterus; tumor	Tumors or cancer of the UTERUS.
vaginal tumor	Tumors or cancer of the VAGINA.
benign tumour of cervix	A non-metastasizing neoplasm that arises from the cervix. Representative examples include squamous papilloma, endocervical polyp, and rhabdomyoma.
benign neoplasm of cervix uteri	A non-metastasizing neoplasm that arises from the cervix. Representative examples include squamous papilloma, endocervical polyp, and rhabdomyoma.
benign neoplasm of uterus, nos	A non-metastasizing neoplasm that arises from the uterine corpus or the cervix. Representative examples include leiomyoma, adenomyoma, and endocervical polyp.
benign neoplasm of vagina (diagnosis)	A non-metastasizing neoplasm that arises from the vagina. Representative examples include squamous papilloma and melanocytic nevus.
benign neoplasm of prostate	A non-metastasizing neoplasm that arises from the prostate. Representative examples include benign phyllodes tumor, leiomyoma, and fibroma.
benign tumor of the ureter	Abnormal growth of the cells of the ureter (upper urinary tract) without malignant characteristics.
abdominal fibromatosis (diagnosis)	A relatively large mass of unusually firm scarlike connective tissue resulting from active participation of fibroblasts, occurring most frequently in the abdominal muscles of women who have borne children. The fibroblasts infiltrate surrounding muscle and fascia. (Stedman, 25th ed)
neoplasm of seminal vesicle	A benign or malignant neoplasm that affects the seminal vesicle. Representative examples include cystadenoma and adenocarcinoma.
intravenous leiomyomatosis of the uterus	A rare benign neoplasm characterized by the presence of smooth muscle cells growing within veins.
benign tumor of seminal vesicle	A non-metastasizing neoplasm that arises from the seminal vesicle.
benign intestinal tumor	A non-metastasizing neoplasm arising from the small or large intestine.
placental neoplasm	An intrauterine mass containing decidual cells (DECIDUA) or with structures resembling the PLACENTA. Deciduomas usually are induced experimentally.
placenta neoplasm	An intrauterine mass containing decidual cells (DECIDUA) or with structures resembling the PLACENTA. Deciduomas usually are induced experimentally.
benign neoplasm of placenta (disorder)	A non-metastasizing neoplasm that arises from the placenta. Representative examples include hemangioma and polyp.
neoplasm of ovary	Tumors or cancer of the OVARY. These neoplasms can be benign or malignant. They are classified according to the tissue of origin, such as the surface EPITHELIUM, the stromal endocrine cells, and the totipotent GERM CELLS.
emgd	A premalignant neoplastic process that affects the endometrial epithelium and glands. It is characterized by architectural glandular alterations and cytological abnormalities in the epithelial cells. The lesion exceeds 1 mm in maximum linear dimension.
tumor	New abnormal growth of tissue. Malignant neoplasms show a greater degree of anaplasia and have the properties of invasion and metastasis, compared to benign neoplasms.
neoplasms nos	New abnormal growth of tissue. Malignant neoplasms show a greater degree of anaplasia and have the properties of invasion and metastasis, compared to benign neoplasms.
processes, neoplastic	The pathological mechanisms and forms taken by tissue during degeneration into a neoplasm and its subsequent activity.
anatomy	tree section heading for anatomical, physiological, and related terms.
anal neoplasms, benign and malignant	Tumors or cancer of the ANAL CANAL.
biliary tract neoplasms	Tumors or cancer in the BILIARY TRACT including the BILE DUCTS and the GALLBLADDER.
bladder neopl	new abnormal urinary bladder tissue that grows by excessive cellular division and proliferation more rapidly than normal and continues to grow after the stimuli that initiated the new growth cease.
bladder neoplasm	new abnormal urinary bladder tissue that grows by excessive cellular division and proliferation more rapidly than normal and continues to grow after the stimuli that initiated the new growth cease.
cervical neoplasm	new abnormal cervical tissue that grows by excessive cellular division and proliferation more rapidly than normal and continues to grow after the stimuli that initiated the new growth cease.
malignant hydatidiform mole	A uterine tumor derived from persistent gestational TROPHOBLASTS, most likely after a molar pregnancy (HYDATIDIFORM MOLE). Invasive hyadatiform mole develops in about 15% of patients after evacuation of a complete mole and less frequently after other types of gestation. It may perforate the MYOMETRIUM and erode uterine vessels causing hemorrhage.
endometrial neoplasm	Tumors or cancer of ENDOMETRIUM, the mucous lining of the UTERUS. These neoplasms can be benign or malignant. Their classification and grading are based on the various cell types and the percent of undifferentiated cells.
fallopian tube neoplasm	Benign or malignant neoplasms of the FALLOPIAN TUBES. They are uncommon. If they develop, they may be located in the wall or within the lumen as a growth attached to the wall by a stalk.
intestines neoplasm	Tumors or cancer of the INTESTINES.
intestines neopl	Tumors or cancer of the INTESTINES.
tumour of pancreas	Tumors or cancer of the PANCREAS. Depending on the types of ISLET CELLS present in the tumors, various hormones can be secreted: GLUCAGON from PANCREATIC ALPHA CELLS; INSULIN from PANCREATIC BETA CELLS; and SOMATOSTATIN from the SOMATOSTATIN-SECRETING CELLS. Most are malignant except the insulin-producing tumors (INSULINOMA).
pelvis neopl	Tumors or cancer of the pelvic region.
peritoneal neoplasm	Tumors or cancer of the PERITONEUM.
abdomen neoplasm	New abnormal growth of tissue in the ABDOMEN.
neoplasia prostate	Tumors or cancer of the PROSTATE.
tumor of retroperitoneum	New abnormal growth of tissue in the RETROPERITONEAL SPACE.
ureter neoplasms	Cancer or tumors of the URETER which may cause obstruction leading to hydroureter, HYDRONEPHROSIS, and PYELONEPHRITIS. HEMATURIA is a common symptom.
urethral tumor	Cancer or tumors of the URETHRA. Benign epithelial tumors of the urethra usually consist of squamous and transitional cells. Primary urethral carcinomas are rare and typically of squamous cells. Urethral carcinoma is the only urological malignancy that is more common in females than in males.
uterine tumor	Tumors or cancer of the UTERUS.
vaginal neoplasm	Tumors or cancer of the VAGINA.
benign neoplasm of the uterine cervix	A non-metastasizing neoplasm that arises from the cervix. Representative examples include squamous papilloma, endocervical polyp, and rhabdomyoma.
uterine tumors, benign	A non-metastasizing neoplasm that arises from the uterine corpus or the cervix. Representative examples include leiomyoma, adenomyoma, and endocervical polyp.
benign neoplasm vagina nos (disorder)	A non-metastasizing neoplasm that arises from the vagina. Representative examples include squamous papilloma and melanocytic nevus.
benign prostate neoplasm	A non-metastasizing neoplasm that arises from the prostate. Representative examples include benign phyllodes tumor, leiomyoma, and fibroma.
neoplasm benign;ureter	Abnormal growth of the cells of the ureter (upper urinary tract) without malignant characteristics.
abdominal desmoid tumor	A relatively large mass of unusually firm scarlike connective tissue resulting from active participation of fibroblasts, occurring most frequently in the abdominal muscles of women who have borne children. The fibroblasts infiltrate surrounding muscle and fascia. (Stedman, 25th ed)
tumor of seminal vesicle	A benign or malignant neoplasm that affects the seminal vesicle. Representative examples include cystadenoma and adenocarcinoma.
intravenous leiomyomatosis	A rare benign neoplasm characterized by the presence of smooth muscle cells growing within veins.
benign neoplasm of seminal vesicle	A non-metastasizing neoplasm that arises from the seminal vesicle.
benign intestine neoplasm	A non-metastasizing neoplasm arising from the small or large intestine.
neoplasm of placenta	An intrauterine mass containing decidual cells (DECIDUA) or with structures resembling the PLACENTA. Deciduomas usually are induced experimentally.
placental neoplasm nos	An intrauterine mass containing decidual cells (DECIDUA) or with structures resembling the PLACENTA. Deciduomas usually are induced experimentally.
benign tumor of placenta	A non-metastasizing neoplasm that arises from the placenta. Representative examples include hemangioma and polyp.
ovarian neoplasm	Tumors or cancer of the OVARY. These neoplasms can be benign or malignant. They are classified according to the tissue of origin, such as the surface EPITHELIUM, the stromal endocrine cells, and the totipotent GERM CELLS.
endomet intraepithl neop	A premalignant neoplastic process that affects the endometrial epithelium and glands. It is characterized by architectural glandular alterations and cytological abnormalities in the epithelial cells. The lesion exceeds 1 mm in maximum linear dimension.
neoplasm	New abnormal growth of tissue. Malignant neoplasms show a greater degree of anaplasia and have the properties of invasion and metastasis, compared to benign neoplasms.
neoplasms	New abnormal growth of tissue. Malignant neoplasms show a greater degree of anaplasia and have the properties of invasion and metastasis, compared to benign neoplasms.
neoplastic processes	The pathological mechanisms and forms taken by tissue during degeneration into a neoplasm and its subsequent activity.
anatomical structure	tree section heading for anatomical, physiological, and related terms.
citrate of magnesia	The citrate salt of the element magnesium with cathartic activity. The cathartic action of magnesium cations appears to result, in part, from osmotically mediated water retention, which subsequently stimulates peristalsis. In addition, magnesium ions may also stimulate the activity of nitric oxide (NO) synthase and increase the biosynthesis of the phospholipid proinflammatory mediator platelet activating factor (PAF) in the gut. NO may stimulate intestinal secretion via prostglandin- and cyclic GMP-dependent mechanisms while PAF produces significant stimulation of colonic secretion and gastrointestinal motility. Check for "https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/intervention/C29241" active clinical trials using this agent. ("http://ncit.nci.nih.gov/ncitbrowser/ConceptReport.jsp?dictionary=NCI%20Thesaurus&code=C29241" NCI Thesaurus)
dioctyl sodium sulfosuccinate	The sodium salt of docusate, a dioctyl salt and an emollient laxative with stool-softening activity. Docusate decreases surface tension and emulsification of fecal matter and allows water to penetrate and mix with stool. As a result, it softens the stool.
docusate calcium	The calcium salt of docusate, a dioctyl salt and an emollient laxative with stool-softening activity. Docusate decreases surface tension and emulsification of fecal matter and allows water to penetrate and mix with stool. As a result, it softens the stool.
alosetron hydrochloride	The hydrochloride salt form of alosetron, a potent and selective 5-HT3 receptor antagonist. Alosetron blocks the actions of serotonin at 5-HT3 sites in the peripheral nervous system, particularly on enteric and nociceptive sensory neurons, thereby affecting the regulation of visceral pain, decreasing gastrointestinal contraction and motility, and decreasing gastrointestinal secretions. This agent is used to treat diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome in women.
alosetron	A potent and selective 5-HT3 receptor antagonist. Alosetron blocks the actions of serotonin at 5-HT3 sites in the peripheral nervous system, particularly on enteric and nociceptive sensory neurons, thereby affecting the regulation of visceral pain, decreasing gastrointestinal contraction and motility, and decreasing gastrointestinal secretions. This agent is used to treat diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome in women.
[d]abdominal pain nos	Sensation of discomfort, distress, or agony in the abdominal region.
elagolix	An orally bioavailable, second-generation, non-peptide based, small molecule compound and selective gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH; LHRH) receptor antagonist, with potential hormone production inhibitory activity. Upon oral administration, elagolix competes with GnRH for receptor binding and inhibits GnRH receptor signaling in the anterior pituitary gland. This inhibits the secretion of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle stimulating hormone (FSH). In males, the inhibition of LH secretion prevents the release of testosterone. In women, inhibition of FSH and LH prevents the production of estrogen by the ovaries. Inhibition of GnRH signaling may treat or prevent symptoms of sex hormone-dependent disease states.
epigastric pain	Pain that is localized to the region of the upper abdomen immediately below the ribs. [https://www.healthgrades.com/symptoms/epigastric-pain, ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
stomach pain	Sensation of discomfort, distress, or agony in the abdominal region.
stomachache	A painful sensation in the stomach.
colic [d] (finding)	A clinical syndrome with intermittent abdominal pain characterized by sudden onset and cessation that is commonly seen in infants. It is usually associated with obstruction of the INTESTINES; of the CYSTIC DUCT; or of the URINARY TRACT.
peritoneal pain	Painful sensation in the peritoneum.
pain abdominal	Sensation of discomfort, distress, or agony in the abdominal region.
[d]abdominal pain (context-dependent category)	Sensation of discomfort, distress, or agony in the abdominal region.
stomach ache	A painful sensation in the stomach.
[d]colic nos	A clinical syndrome with intermittent abdominal pain characterized by sudden onset and cessation that is commonly seen in infants. It is usually associated with obstruction of the INTESTINES; of the CYSTIC DUCT; or of the URINARY TRACT.
pain in the flank	Smärta som utgår från området mellan nedre revbenskanten och höftbenskammen.
tummy ache	A painful sensation in the stomach.
ache stomach	A painful sensation in the stomach.
[d]abdominal colic (situation)	A clinical syndrome with intermittent abdominal pain characterized by sudden onset and cessation that is commonly seen in infants. It is usually associated with obstruction of the INTESTINES; of the CYSTIC DUCT; or of the URINARY TRACT.
abdominal colic (finding)	A clinical syndrome with intermittent abdominal pain characterized by sudden onset and cessation that is commonly seen in infants. It is usually associated with obstruction of the INTESTINES; of the CYSTIC DUCT; or of the URINARY TRACT.
indigestion	Impaired digestion, especially after eating.
pain (finding)	An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
pelvis painful	Pain in the pelvic region of genital and non-genital origin.
diseases of peritoneum	Pathological processes involving the PERITONEUM.
stomach diseases	Pathological processes involving the STOMACH.
gas	presence of excessive amounts of air or gas in the stomach or intestine, leading to distention of the organs.
sickle cell anaemia	A disease characterized by chronic hemolytic anemia, episodic painful crises, and pathologic involvement of many organs. It is the clinical expression of homozygosity for hemoglobin S.
alpha-galactosidase a deficiency disease	An X-linked inherited metabolic disease caused by a deficiency of lysosomal ALPHA-GALACTOSIDASE A. It is characterized by intralysosomal accumulation of globotriaosylceramide and other GLYCOSPHINGOLIPIDS in blood vessels throughout the body leading to multi-system complications including renal, cardiac, cerebrovascular, and skin disorders.
crohn's disease [regional enteritis]	A chronic transmural inflammation that may involve any part of the DIGESTIVE TRACT from MOUTH to ANUS, mostly found in the ILEUM, the CECUM, and the COLON. In Crohn disease, the inflammation, extending through the intestinal wall from the MUCOSA to the serosa, is characteristically asymmetric and segmental. Epithelioid GRANULOMAS may be seen in some patients.
aldb - aldolase b deficiency	An autosomal recessive fructose metabolism disorder due to deficient fructose-1-phosphate aldolase (EC 2.1.2.13) activity, resulting in accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate. The accumulated fructose-1-phosphate inhibits glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis, causing severe hypoglycemia following ingestion of fructose. Prolonged fructose ingestion in infants leads ultimately to hepatic failure and death. Patients develop a strong distaste for sweet food, and avoid a chronic course of the disease by remaining on a fructose- and sucrose-free diet.
familial mediterranean fever with recurrent polyserositis	A group of HEREDITARY AUTOINFLAMMATION DISEASES, characterized by recurrent fever, abdominal pain, headache, rash, PLEURISY; and ARTHRITIS. ORCHITIS; benign MENINGITIS; and AMYLOIDOSIS may also occur. Homozygous or compound heterozygous mutations in marenostrin gene encoding PYRIN result in autosomal recessive transmission; simple heterozygous, autosomal dominant form of the disease also exists with mutations in the same gene.
ovarian hyperstimulation syndromes	A complication of OVULATION INDUCTION in infertility treatment. It is graded by the severity of symptoms which include OVARY enlargement, multiple OVARIAN FOLLICLES; OVARIAN CYSTS; ASCITES; and generalized EDEMA. The full-blown syndrome may lead to RENAL FAILURE, respiratory distress, and even DEATH. Increased capillary permeability is caused by the vasoactive substances, such as VASCULAR ENDOTHELIAL GROWTH FACTORS, secreted by the overly-stimulated OVARIES.
cyclical vomiting syndrome	A condition characterized by recurrent, self-limiting episodes of vomiting associated with intense nausea, pallor, and lethargy. It is commonly a migraine precursor.
hereditary coproporphyria	An autosomal dominant inherited disorder of porphyrin metabolism caused by deficiency of the enzyme coproporphyrinogen oxidase. It results in neurologic damage and can include abdominal pain, constipation and psychiatric manifestations.
protocoproporphyria	Vrozená porfyrie s autozomálně dominantní dědičností, způsobená sníženou aktivitou protoporfyrinogenoxidázy. Manifestuje se podobně jako jiné akutní hepatální porfyrie (zejm. jako akutní intermitentní porfyrie), často po působení noxy (barbituráty, steroidy, alkohol aj.). Vždy je přítomna fotosenzitivita. Ve stolici je vysoký obsah koproporfyrinu a protoporfyrinu, fluorescence plasmy vykazuje specifické emise. Léčba je stejná jako u akutní intermitentní porfyrie, navíc je ještě nutná péče o kůži. (cit. Velký lékařský slovník online, 2017 http://lekarske.slovniky.cz)
porphyrias, acute intermittent	An autosomal dominant porphyria that is due to a deficiency of HYDROXYMETHYLBILANE SYNTHASE in the LIVER, the third enzyme in the 8-enzyme biosynthetic pathway of HEME. Clinical features are recurrent and life-threatening neurologic disturbances, ABDOMINAL PAIN, and elevated level of AMINOLEVULINIC ACID and PORPHOBILINOGEN in the urine.
gitelman syndrome	An inherited renal disorder characterized by defective NaCl reabsorption in the convoluted DISTAL KIDNEY TUBULE leading to HYPOKALEMIA. In contrast with BARTTER SYNDROME, Gitelman syndrome includes hypomagnesemia and normocalcemic hypocalciuria, and is caused by mutations in the thiazide-sensitive SODIUM-POTASSIUM-CHLORIDE SYMPORTERS.
pyroglutamate hydrolase deficiency	Decreased level of the reaction 5-oxo-L-proline + ATP + 2 H(2)O = L-glutamate + ADP + 2 H(+) + phosphate. [PMID:6790862]
cronkhite-canada syndrome	Nespecifický polypózní syndrom, který je charakterizován přítomností difuzní gastrointestinální polypózy, průjmem a exsudativní enteropatií. Poprvé byl tento syndrom hlášen v roce 1955 Cronkhitem a Canadovou.
infundibulopelvic stenosis multicystic kidney syndrome (disorder)	A rare genetic renal malformation syndrome with characteristics of variable degrees of malformation in the pelvicalyceal system (including unilateral or bilateral calyceal dilatation, infundibular stenosis, hypoplasia or stenosis of the renal pelvis) which lead to multicystic kidney. Clinically it exhibits abdominal, lumbar or flank pain, recurrent urinary tract infections, hypertension, proteinuria and often progresses to renal insufficiency. Calyceal dilatation and hydronephrosis are frequently seen on imaging.
polyposis, gastric	Multiple polyps in the acid-secreting mucosa of the gastric body and fundus. Fundic gland polyps (FGP) are usually 1 to 5 mm in size, though larger polyps have been found. FGPs are typically sessile, shiny, translucent, pale to pinkish in color (resembling the surrounding mucosa), and often exhibit tiny surface blood vessels. These polyps have characteristically been observed to chunk off or detach entirely at the base when removed with cold forceps, in contrast to other types of gastric polyps. [PMID:20567540]
delta storage pool disease	An autosomal recessive sub-type of Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome caused by mutation(s) in the HPS1 gene, encoding Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome 1 protein. This sub-type is associated with pulmonary fibrosis.
mvah	An extremely rare autosomal recessive inherited disorder caused by mutations in the GCGR gene. It is characterized by the presence of islet glucagon cell hyperplasia and glucagon cell tumors.
abdomen; colic	A clinical syndrome with intermittent abdominal pain characterized by sudden onset and cessation that is commonly seen in infants. It is usually associated with obstruction of the INTESTINES; of the CYSTIC DUCT; or of the URINARY TRACT.
pain epigastric	Pain that is localized to the region of the upper abdomen immediately below the ribs. [https://www.healthgrades.com/symptoms/epigastric-pain, ORCID:0000-0001-5208-3432]
inguinodynia	An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the groin region. []
abdominal migraines	Paroxysmal episodes of intense, acute periumbilical pain that lasts for one or more hours with intervening periods of usual health lasting weeks to months, with no evidence of an inflammatory, anatomic, metabolic, or neoplastic process that explains the symptoms. The pain interferes with normal activities and is associated with at least two of the following symptoms: anorexia, nausea, vomiting, headache, photophobia, and/or pallor.
colic [d]	A clinical syndrome with intermittent abdominal pain characterized by sudden onset and cessation that is commonly seen in infants. It is usually associated with obstruction of the INTESTINES; of the CYSTIC DUCT; or of the URINARY TRACT.
abdominal colic	A clinical syndrome with intermittent abdominal pain characterized by sudden onset and cessation that is commonly seen in infants. It is usually associated with obstruction of the INTESTINES; of the CYSTIC DUCT; or of the URINARY TRACT.
groin pain	An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the groin region. []
infantile colic (finding)	Consistent pattern of crying in a healthy infant between 3 weeks and 3 months of age. Often defined as lasting 3 hours a day more than 3 days a week for at least 3 weeks in a row.
migraine abdominal	Paroxysmal episodes of intense, acute periumbilical pain that lasts for one or more hours with intervening periods of usual health lasting weeks to months, with no evidence of an inflammatory, anatomic, metabolic, or neoplastic process that explains the symptoms. The pain interferes with normal activities and is associated with at least two of the following symptoms: anorexia, nausea, vomiting, headache, photophobia, and/or pallor.
pain; abdominal	Sensation of discomfort, distress, or agony in the abdominal region.
[d]symptoms (situation)	Subjective evidence of disease perceived by the patient.
acute abdomen (disorder)	A clinical syndrome with acute abdominal pain that is severe, localized, and rapid in onset. Acute abdomen may be caused by a variety of disorders, injuries, or diseases.
abdominal guarding	A voluntary contraction of the abdominal wall musculature to avoid pain. []
abdominal pain, episodic	An intermittent form of abdominal pain. [HPO:probinson]
painful	An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
abdominal symptom	A subjective manifestation of disease localized to the abdomen. []
gastro pain	A disorder characterized by a sensation of marked discomfort in the gastrointestinal region.
abdmnal pain unspcf site	Sensation of discomfort, distress, or agony in the abdominal region.
gastrointestinal perforation, ulcer, hemorrhage, obstruction non-specific findings/procedures (smq)	SMQ Gastrointestinal perforation, ulceration, haemorrhage or obstruction is intended to identify relevant MedDRA terms used in a search for cases of possible gastrointestinal perforation, ulceration, haemorrhage or obstruction. This sub-search SMQ is intended for use in conjunction with the other sub-SMQs.
gastrointestinal ulceration (smq)	This SMQ is intended to identify relevant MedDRA terms used in a search for cases of possible gastrointestinal perforation, ulceration, haemorrhage or obstruction. Gastrointestinal ulceration: Ulceration is a local defect or excavation of surface of an organ or tissue; produced by sloughing of inflammatorynecrotic tissue.
pain gi	A disorder characterized by a sensation of marked discomfort in the gastrointestinal region.
gastrointestinal perforation, ulcer, haemorrhage, obstruction non-specific findings/procedures (smq)	SMQ Gastrointestinal perforation, ulceration, haemorrhage or obstruction is intended to identify relevant MedDRA terms used in a search for cases of possible gastrointestinal perforation, ulceration, haemorrhage or obstruction. This sub-search SMQ is intended for use in conjunction with the other sub-SMQs.
gastrointestinal pains	A disorder characterized by a sensation of marked discomfort in the gastrointestinal region.
gastrointestinal pain	A disorder characterized by a sensation of marked discomfort in the gastrointestinal region.
gi pain	A disorder characterized by a sensation of marked discomfort in the gastrointestinal region.
anxiety	Feelings or emotions of dread, apprehension, and impending disaster but not disabling as with ANXIETY DISORDERS.
constipation nos	Infrequent or difficult evacuation of FECES. These symptoms are associated with a variety of causes, including low DIETARY FIBER intake, emotional or nervous disturbances, systemic and structural disorders, drug-induced aggravation, and infections.
d - diarrhoea	An increased liquidity or decreased consistency of FECES, such as running stool. Fecal consistency is related to the ratio of water-holding capacity of insoluble solids to total water, rather than the amount of water present. Diarrhea is not hyperdefecation or increased fecal weight.
body nutrition deficit	Intake of nutrients insufficient to meet metabolic needs.
latex allergy reaction	A hypersensitive reaction to natural latex rubber products.
stomach pain (diagnosis)	A painful sensation in the stomach.
[d]colic nos (situation)	A clinical syndrome with intermittent abdominal pain characterized by sudden onset and cessation that is commonly seen in infants. It is usually associated with obstruction of the INTESTINES; of the CYSTIC DUCT; or of the URINARY TRACT.
pain;peritoneal	Painful sensation in the peritoneum.
urination pain	Painful URINATION. It is often associated with infections of the lower URINARY TRACT.
low back pain (finding)	Acute or chronic pain in the lumbar or sacral regions, which may be associated with musculo-ligamentous SPRAINS AND STRAINS; INTERVERTEBRAL DISK DISPLACEMENT; and other conditions.
low backaches	Acute or chronic pain in the lumbar or sacral regions, which may be associated with musculo-ligamentous SPRAINS AND STRAINS; INTERVERTEBRAL DISK DISPLACEMENT; and other conditions.
pain in rectum	A disorder characterized by a sensation of marked discomfort in the rectal region.
hepatic colic -retired-	A disorder characterized by a sensation of marked discomfort in the gallbladder region.
urethralgia	A painful sensation in the urethra.
intermenstrual; pain	A disorder characterized by marked discomfort sensation in one side of the abdomen between menstrual cycles, around the time of the discharge of the ovum from the ovarian follicle.
ache;stomach	A painful sensation in the stomach.
lower abdominal pain	A sensation of discomfort emanating from the inferior quadrants of the abdomen, which may be peritoneal or visceral in origin, or referred from an extra-abdominal location.
bladder pain (symptom)	Painful sensation in the bladder region.
pain;vaginal	A painful sensation in the vagina.
anal pain	Painful sensation in the anal region.
prostatodynia	Pain in the prostate gland.
abdominal migraine	Paroxysmal episodes of intense, acute periumbilical pain that lasts for one or more hours with intervening periods of usual health lasting weeks to months, with no evidence of an inflammatory, anatomic, metabolic, or neoplastic process that explains the symptoms. The pain interferes with normal activities and is associated with at least two of the following symptoms: anorexia, nausea, vomiting, headache, photophobia, and/or pallor.
painful spasm of anus (finding)	Recurrent episodes of pain localized to the anus or lower rectum which lasts seconds to minutes. There is no pain between episodes.
pain hepatic	A painful sensation in the liver.
uterine pain (diagnosis)	A disorder characterized by a sensation of marked discomfort in the uterus.
pudendal neuralgia	Pain associated with a damaged PUDENDAL NERVE. Clinical features may include positional pain with sitting in the perineal and genital areas, sexual dysfunction and FECAL INCONTINENCE and URINARY INCONTINENCE.
system, nervous	The entire nerve apparatus, composed of a central part, the brain and spinal cord, and a peripheral part, the cranial and spinal nerves, autonomic ganglia, and plexuses. (Stedman, 26th ed)
neurological function	Egenskaper och processer typiska för nervsystemet som helhet eller med avseende på det perifera eller centrala nervsystemet.
pain stomach	A painful sensation in the stomach.

passing water hurts	Painful URINATION. It is often associated with infections of the lower URINARY TRACT.
lbp - low back pain	Acute or chronic pain in the lumbar or sacral regions, which may be associated with musculo-ligamentous SPRAINS AND STRAINS; INTERVERTEBRAL DISK DISPLACEMENT; and other conditions.

[d]colic nos (context-dependent category)	A clinical syndrome with intermittent abdominal pain characterized by sudden onset and cessation that is commonly seen in infants. It is usually associated with obstruction of the INTESTINES; of the CYSTIC DUCT; or of the URINARY TRACT.
lower abdominal pain (symptom)	A sensation of discomfort emanating from the inferior quadrants of the abdomen, which may be peritoneal or visceral in origin, or referred from an extra-abdominal location.
bladder pains	Painful sensation in the bladder region.
pain vagina	A painful sensation in the vagina.
pain anus	Painful sensation in the anal region.
groin pains	An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the groin region. []
pain prostatic	Pain in the prostate gland.
proctalgia fugax	Recurrent episodes of pain localized to the anus or lower rectum which lasts seconds to minutes. There is no pain between episodes.
hepatic pain (diagnosis)	A painful sensation in the liver.
uterine pain	A disorder characterized by a sensation of marked discomfort in the uterus.
neuralgia, pudendal	Pain associated with a damaged PUDENDAL NERVE. Clinical features may include positional pain with sitting in the perineal and genital areas, sexual dysfunction and FECAL INCONTINENCE and URINARY INCONTINENCE.
neurologic body system	The entire nerve apparatus, composed of a central part, the brain and spinal cord, and a peripheral part, the cranial and spinal nerves, autonomic ganglia, and plexuses. (Stedman, 26th ed)
pain; stomach	A painful sensation in the stomach.
[d]colic	A clinical syndrome with intermittent abdominal pain characterized by sudden onset and cessation that is commonly seen in infants. It is usually associated with obstruction of the INTESTINES; of the CYSTIC DUCT; or of the URINARY TRACT.
sore tummy	A painful sensation in the stomach.
stomach; pain	A painful sensation in the stomach.
[d]abdominal migraine (context-dependent category)	Paroxysmal episodes of intense, acute periumbilical pain that lasts for one or more hours with intervening periods of usual health lasting weeks to months, with no evidence of an inflammatory, anatomic, metabolic, or neoplastic process that explains the symptoms. The pain interferes with normal activities and is associated with at least two of the following symptoms: anorexia, nausea, vomiting, headache, photophobia, and/or pallor.
gardner's syndrome	A variant of ADENOMATOUS POLYPOSIS COLI caused by mutation in the APC gene (GENES, APC) on CHROMOSOME 5. It is characterized by not only the presence of multiple colonic polyposis but also extracolonic ADENOMATOUS POLYPS in the UPPER GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT; the EYE; the SKIN; the SKULL; and the FACIAL BONES; as well as malignancy in organs other than the GI tract.
mediterranean lymphoma	A condition that is caused by HYPERPLASIA of LYMPHOCYTES in the small intestine (INTESTINE, SMALL) and the mesenteric LYMPH NODES. These lymphocytes produce an anomalous alpha heavy chain protein. Generally, these IPSID patients have either concurrent LYMPHOMA or develop lymphoma within a few years. The disease was first described in the Mediterranean region and is characterized by malabsorption; WEIGHT LOSS; DIARRHEA; and STEATORRHEA.
wilms tumor (nephroblastoma)	pediatric nephroblastoma originating from embryonic kidney stem cells; usually affects children before the fifth year, but may occur in the fetus or rarely in later life; caused by defects in one or more tumor suppressor genes.
polyposis, myh-associated	A polyposis syndrome due to an autosomal dominant mutation of the APC genes (GENES, APC) on CHROMOSOME 5. The syndrome is characterized by the development of hundreds of ADENOMATOUS POLYPS in the COLON and RECTUM of affected individuals by early adulthood.
cholangiocarcinomas	A malignant tumor arising from the epithelium of the BILE DUCTS.
klatskin tumor	Nádor v horní oblasti vývodných žlučových cest (karcinom ductus hepaticus) s projevy obstrukčního ikteru; nádor je malý, metastazuje pomalu. (cit. Velký lékařský slovník online, 2015 http://lekarske.slovniky.cz/ )
cystadenocarcinoma of the pancreas	A cystic adenocarcinoma that arises from the pancreas. It includes the acinar cell and serous cystadenocarcinoma subtypes.
stage ii cancer of the colon ajcc v6	Stage II includes: IIA (T3, N0, M0); IIB (T4, N0, M0). T3: Tumor invades through the muscularis propria or into non-peritonealized pericolic or perirectal tissues. T4: Tumor directly invades other organs or structures, and/or perforates visceral peritoneum. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th ed.)
colon cancer dukes c	Stage III includes: IIIA (T1-T2, N1, M0); IIIB (T3-T4, N1, M0); IIIC (Any T, N2, M0). N1: Metastasis in 1 to 3 regional lymph nodes. N2: Metastasis in 4 or more regional lymph nodes. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th ed.)
stage ii rectal carcinoma ajcc v6	Stage II includes IIA (T3, N0, M0) and IIB (T4, N0, M0). T3: Tumor invades through the muscularis propria into the subserosa, or into nonperitonealized pericolic or perirectal tissues. T4: Tumor directly invades other organs or structures, and/or perforates the visceral peritoneum. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th ed.)
stage iii rectal carcinoma ajcc v6	Stage III includes: IIIA (T1-T2, N0, M0); IIIB (T3-T4, N1, M0); IIIC (Any T, N2, M0). N1: Metastasis in 1 to 3 regional lymph nodes. N2: Metastasis in 4 or more regional lymph nodes. (AJCC 6th ed.)
nephroblastoma, stage i	The tumor was completely removed by surgery and all of the following are true: (1) cancer was found only in the kidney and did not spread to blood vessels of the kidney; (2) the outer layer of the kidney did not break open; (3) the tumor did not break open; (4) a biopsy of the tumor was not done; and (5) no cancer cells were found at the edges of the area where the tumor was removed.
wilms' tumor, stage ii	Cancer spread out of the kidney to nearby soft tissue or to blood vessels of the kidney and was completely removed by surgery. No cancer cells were found at the edges of the area where the cancer was removed.
stage iii nephroblastoma	Cancer remains in the abdomen after surgery and at least one of the following is true: (1) cancer has spread to lymph nodes in the abdomen or pelvis (the part of the body between the hips); (2) cancer has spread to or through the surface of the peritoneum (the layer of tissue that lines the abdominal cavity and covers most organs in the abdomen); (3) a biopsy of the tumor was done during surgery to remove it; (4) the tumor was removed in more than one piece.
stage iv wilms tumor	Cancer has spread through the blood to organs such as the lungs, liver, bone, or brain, or to lymph nodes outside of the abdomen and pelvis (the part of the body between the hips).
wilms tumor, stage v	Cancer cells are found in both kidneys when the disease is first diagnosed. Each kidney is staged separately as I, II, III, or IV.
recurrent renal adenosarcoma	The reemergence of Wilms tumor of the kidney after a period of remission.
adenocarcinoma of the duodenum	A malignant epithelial tumor with a glandular organization that originates in the duodenum. [HPO:probinson]
epithelial predominant renal adenosarcoma	Wilms tumor of the kidney characterized by the predominance of the epithelial component. The epithelial cells may form papillary and tubular patterns and pseudorosettes.
blastema predominant renal wilms tumor	Wilms tumor of the kidney characterized by the predominance of the blastema component.
stromal predominant wilms tumor	Wilms tumor of the kidney characterized by the predominance of the mesenchymal component.
mixed cell type wilms tumor	Wilms tumor of the kidney characterized by the presence of blastema, epithelial, and mesenchymal components (triphasic pattern) or a combination of two of them (biphasic pattern).
gastric intestinal-type adenocarcinoma	An adenocarcinoma of the stomach arising on a background of intestinal metaplasia. Microscopically, it is characterized by a glandular pattern and it closely resembles a colonic adenocarcinoma. Grossly, it tends to be nodular, polypoid or ulcerated.
colloid adenocarcinoma of colon	An invasive adenocarcinoma of the colon characterized by the presence of pools of extracellular mucin. Malignant glandular epithelial cells are present in the mucin collections. Mucin constitutes more than 50% of the lesion. Check for "https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/intervention/C7966" active clinical trials using this agent. ("http://ncit.nci.nih.gov/ncitbrowser/ConceptReport.jsp?dictionary=NCI%20Thesaurus&code=C7966" NCI Thesaurus)
carcinoma simplex of the colon.	An invasive malignant epithelial tumor that arises from the colon. There is no morphologic, immunophenotypic, or molecular biological evidence of glandular or squamous differentiation.
gallbladder adenocarcinoma	An adenocarcinoma arising from the gallbladder. It is the most common malignant tumor of the gallbladder and it is usually well to moderately differentiated. The incidence is higher in patients with gallstones than in patients without gallstones. Signs and symptoms usually present late in the course of the disease and are reminiscent of those of chronic cholecystitis including right upper quadrant pain. Histologic variants include adenocarcinoma of the intestinal type, clear cell adenocarcinoma, mucinous adenocarcinoma, papillary adenocarcinoma, and signet ring adenocarcinoma. Check for "https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/intervention/C9166" active clinical trials using this agent. ("http://ncit.nci.nih.gov/ncitbrowser/ConceptReport.jsp?dictionary=NCI%20Thesaurus&code=C9166" NCI Thesaurus)
rectal mucinous adenocarcinoma	An invasive adenocarcinoma of the rectum characterized by the presence of pools of extracellular mucin. Malignant glandular epithelial cells are present in the mucin collections. Mucin constitutes more than 50% of the lesion. Check for "https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/intervention/C7973" active clinical trials using this agent. ("http://ncit.nci.nih.gov/ncitbrowser/ConceptReport.jsp?dictionary=NCI%20Thesaurus&code=C7973" NCI Thesaurus)
anaplastic carcinoma of gallbladder	A carcinoma without evidence of differentiation arising from the gallbladder. The most common variant is the spindle and giant cell type which resembles a sarcoma.
rectal signet ring cell adenocarcinoma	An infiltrating adenocarcinoma arising from the rectum. It is characterized by the presence of malignant glandular cells with prominent intracytoplasmic mucin. These cells constitute more than 50% of the malignant cellular population.
gallbladder adenocarcinoma with squamous metaplasia	An infiltrating adenocarcinoma of the gallbladder characterized by the presence of metaplastic changes of the malignant glandular cells to squamous cells. Check for "https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/intervention/C9169" active clinical trials using this agent. ("http://ncit.nci.nih.gov/ncitbrowser/ConceptReport.jsp?dictionary=NCI%20Thesaurus&code=C9169" NCI Thesaurus)
gallbladder, squamous cell carcinoma of the	A squamous cell carcinoma arising from the gallbladder. It is composed entirely of squamous cells and it may arise from areas of squamous metaplasia (WHO, 2000). Check for "https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/intervention/C9170" active clinical trials using this agent. ("http://ncit.nci.nih.gov/ncitbrowser/ConceptReport.jsp?dictionary=NCI%20Thesaurus&code=C9170" NCI Thesaurus)
adenocarcinoma of extrahepatic bile duct	An adenocarcinoma arising from the epithelium of the extrahepatic bile duct. Signs and symptoms include abdominal pain, anorexia, jaundice, pruritus, nausea and vomiting, and weight loss. Check for "https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/intervention/C7975" active clinical trials using this agent. ("http://ncit.nci.nih.gov/ncitbrowser/ConceptReport.jsp?dictionary=NCI%20Thesaurus&code=C7975" NCI Thesaurus)
acinar cell adenocarcinoma of pancreas	A very rare malignant epithelial tumor of the pancreas characterized, macroscopically by a usually large well-circumscribed fully or partially encapsulated solid mass often with hemorrhage, necrosis and cystic changes in any portion of the pancreas. Histological characteristics are neoplastic cells with variable degrees of differentiation and morphology ranging from acinar structures similar to normal pancreatic acini to large sheets of poorly differentiated neoplastic cells. Presenting symptoms are typically non-specific and include abdominal pain, weight loss, vomiting, nausea, and/or less commonly jaundice. Immunohistochemical evidence of acinar-specific products is observed. Association with Lynch syndrome, familial adenomatous polyposis, and pancreatic panniculitis has been reported.
germ cell tumor, ovarian, recurrent	The reemergence of ovarian germ cell tumor after a period of remission.
mixed germ cell tumor of the ovary	An ovarian malignant germ cell tumor characterized by the presence of at least two different germ cell components. At least one of the germ cell components is primitive. The most common combination of germ cell elements is dysgerminoma and yolk sac tumor. Check for "https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/intervention/C8114" active clinical trials using this agent. ("http://ncit.nci.nih.gov/ncitbrowser/ConceptReport.jsp?dictionary=NCI%20Thesaurus&code=C8114" NCI Thesaurus)
adult cholangiocarcinoma	A cholangiocarcinoma occurring in adults.
pancreatic adenocarcinoma	The presence of an adenocarcinoma of the pancreas. [HPO:probinson]
bile duct cystadenoma	An epithelial, usually multiloculated neoplasm arising from the intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile ducts. It occurs predominantly in females. Signs and symptoms include abdominal mass, abdominal pain, and jaundice. Morphologically, the cystic spaces are lined by columnar epithelium and contain mucinous or serous fluid.
bile duct cystadenocarcinoma	A mucinous cystic neoplasm that arises from the intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile ducts and it is associated with an invasive carcinomatous component.
malignant adrenal gland chromaffin paraganglioma	A pheochromocytoma that metastasizes to other anatomic sites. Common sites of metastasis include lymph nodes, bones, liver, and lung. Morphologic features associated with malignant pheochromocytomas include: atypical mitotic figures, capsular and vascular invasion, tumor cell necrosis, and high mitotic activity.
pancreatoblastoma	A rare pediatric carcinoma of the pancreas. [HPO:sdoelken]
intrahepatic carcinoma of bile duct	A carcinoma that originates in the intrahepatic bile duct epithelium of the intrahepatic biliary tree. Malignant lesions are solid, nodular, and grayish. Most cases are adenocarcinomas. Somatic mutations in BAP1, ARID1A, PBRM1, IDH1, and IDH2 genes have been identified. OMIM: 615619
mesothelioma of peritoneum	An aggressive malignant mesothelioma that arises from the peritoneum. Patients usually present with abdominal pain and ascites.
serous cystadenoma of ovary	A cystic tumor of the ovary, containing thin, clear, yellow serous fluid and varying amounts of solid tissue. [HPO:probinson, PMID:23766763]
embryonal carcinoma of ovary	An embryonal carcinoma arising from the ovary. Signs and symptoms include the presence of an abdominal mass and abdominal pain. Check for "https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/intervention/C8108" active clinical trials using this agent. ("http://ncit.nci.nih.gov/ncitbrowser/ConceptReport.jsp?dictionary=NCI%20Thesaurus&code=C8108" NCI Thesaurus)
early gastric cancer (diagnosis)	An invasive adenocarcinoma confined to the mucosa or mucosa and submucosa of the gastric wall. The regional lymph nodes may or may not be involved. It usually occurs in the lesser curvature. The 5-year survival rate following resection is between 80 percent and 95 percent, and remains high even when lymph node metastases are present.
pelvic lipomatosis (morphologic abnormality)	A neoplastic process characterized by a diffuse poorly circumscribed overgrowth of adipose tissue in the pelvic region. Clinical presentation includes complaints of back and abdominal pain, urinary frequency, perineal pain and constipation. It predominately affects black males.
small intestine neoplasm malignant duodenum carcinoma	A carcinoma that arises from the duodenum. The vast majority of cases are adenocarcinomas.
wilm's tumor predisposition	Familial embryonal neoplasm derived from nephrogenic blastemal cells. Several lines of differentiation, including blastemal, stromal and epithelial, are usually expressed. Comprises approximately 1% of Wilms tumors. (AFIP fascicle version 2.0 mo011000) Check for "https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/intervention/C8496" active clinical trials using this agent. ("http://ncit.nci.nih.gov/ncitbrowser/ConceptReport.jsp?dictionary=NCI%20Thesaurus&code=C8496" NCI Thesaurus)
stage ii colorectal cancer	Stage II includes: IIA (T3, N0, M0); IIB (T4a, N0, M0); IIC (T4b, N0, M0). T3: Tumor invades through the muscularis propria into pericolorectal tissues. T4a: Tumor penetrates to the surface of the visceral peritoneum. T4b: Tumor directly invades or is adherent to other organs or structures. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 7th ed.)
stage iii colorectal carcinoma ajcc v6	Stage III colorectal cancer is divided into stage IIIA, stage IIIB, and stage IIIC. In stage IIIA, (1) cancer may have spread through the mucosa (innermost layer) of the colon and/or rectal wall to the submucosa (layer of tissue under the mucosa) and may have spread to the muscle layer of the colon and/or rectal wall. Cancer has spread to at least one but not more than 3 nearby lymph nodes, or cancer cells have formed in tissues near the lymph nodes; or (2) cancer has spread through the mucosa of the colon and/or rectal wall to the submucosa. Cancer has spread to at least 4 but not more than 6 nearby lymph nodes.In stage IIIB, (1) cancer has spread through the muscle layer of the colon and/or rectal wall to the serosa (outermost layer) of the colon and/or rectal wall or has spread through the serosa but not to nearby organs. Cancer has spread to at least one but not more than 3 nearby lymph nodes, or cancer cells have formed in tissues near the lymph nodes; or (2) cancer has spread to the muscle layer of the colon and/or rectal wall or to the serosa of the colon and/or rectal wall. Cancer has spread to at least 4 but not more than 6 nearby lymph nodes; or (3) cancer has spread through the mucosa of the colon and/or rectal wall to the submucosa and may have spread to the muscle layer of the colon and/or rectal wall. Cancer has spread to 7 or more nearby lymph nodes. In stage IIIC, (1) cancer has spread through the serosa of the colon and/or rectal wall but has not spread to nearby organs. Cancer has spread to at least 4 but not more than 6 nearby lymph nodes; or (2) cancer has spread through the muscle layer of the colon and/or rectal wall to the serosa of the colon and/or rectal wall or has spread through the serosa but has not spread to nearby organs. Cancer has spread to 7 or more nearby lymph nodes; or (3) cancer has spread through the serosa of the colon and/or rectal wall and has spread to nearby organs. Cancer has spread to one or more nearby lymph nodes, or cancer cells have formed in tissues near the lymph nodes.
ovarian germ cell tumor	A germ cell tumor that arises from the ovary and occurs in children.
non-resectable small bowel carcinoma	Carcinoma of the small intestine not amendable to resection.
recurrent carcinoma of the small bowel	The reemergence of small intestine carcinoma after a period of remission.
resectable small intestinal carcinoma	Carcinoma of the small intestine amendable to resection.
advanced peritoneal malignant mesothelioma	A malignant mesothelioma that arises from the peritoneum and has spread in the abdominal cavity. It may result in bowel obstruction.
relapsed malignant mesothelioma of peritoneum	The reemergence of malignant peritoneal mesothelioma after a period of remission.
carcinoma colon dukes d	Stage IV includes: (Any T, Any N, M1). M1: Distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th ed.)
metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma	An adenocarcinoma that arises from the exocrine pancreatic tissue and has metastasized to other anatomic sites.
recurrent pancreatic adenocarcinoma	The reemergence of pancreatic adenocarcinoma after a period of remission.
pancreatic adenocarcinoma resectable	Pancreatic adenocarcinoma that is amenable to surgical resection.
recurrent duodenal cancer	The reemergence of duodenal carcinoma after a period of remission.
resectable duodenal carcinoma	Carcinoma of the duodenum amendable to surgical removal.
adenosquamous carcinoma of the bile duct	A carcinoma that arises from the extrahepatic bile ducts. It is characterized by the presence of glandular and squamous malignant epithelial components.
clear cell adenocarcinoma of bile duct	A morphologic variant of extrahepatic bile duct adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of malignant glandular epithelium composed of clear cells.
mucinous extrahepatic bile duct adenocarcinoma	An adenocarcinoma that arises from the extrahepatic bile ducts. It is characterized by the presence of extracellular mucin that constitutes more than fifty-percent of the tumor.
signet ring cell carcinoma of the bile duct	An adenocarcinoma that arises from the extrahepatic bile ducts. It is characterized by the presence of signet ring malignant epithelial cells.
squamous cell bile duct carcinoma	A carcinoma that arises from the extrahepatic bile ducts. It is composed entirely by malignant squamous epithelial cells.
cholangiocarcinoma non-resectable	Cholangiocarcinoma that is not amenable to surgical resection.
cholangiocarcinoma recurrent	The reemergence of cholangiocarcinoma after a period of remission.
cholangiocarcinoma resectable	Cholangiocarcinoma that is amenable to surgical resection.
ovarian serous cystadenofibroma	A benign neoplasm of the ovary characterized by the presence of cystic structures lined by serous epithelial cells in a fibrotic stroma.
small intestine carcinoma stage i	Stage I includes: (T1, N0, M0); (T2, N0, M0). T1: Tumor invades lamina propria or submucosa. T2: Tumor invades muscularis propria. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 7th ed.)
small intestine carcinoma stage ii	Stage II includes: IIA (T3, N0, M0); IIB (T4, N0, M0). T3: Tumor invades through the muscularis propria into the subserosa or into the nonperitonealized perimuscular tissue (mesentery or retroperitoneum) with extension 2 cm or less. T4: Tumor perforates the visceral peritoneum or directly invades other organs or structures (including other loops of small intestine, mesentery, or retroperitoneum more than 2 cm, and abdominal wall by way of serosa; for duodenum only, invasion of pancreas or bile duct). N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 7th ed.)
stage iii small intestine carcinoma	Stage III includes: IIIA (Any T, N1, M0); IIIB (Any T, N2, M0); N1: Metastasis in 1-3 regional lymph nodes. N2: Metastasis in four or more regional lymph nodes. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 7th ed.)
small intestine carcinoma stage iv	Stage IV includes: Any T, Any N, M1. M1: Distant metastasis. (AJCC 7th ed.)
parietal cell adenocarcinoma	An adenocarcinoma of the stomach arising from the parietal cells. It is characterized by the presence of malignant cells with eosinophilic, finely granular cytoplasm.
kidney embryonal adenoma	A benign, well-circumscribed renal cortical neoplasm affecting females more often than males. Polycythemia has been reported in twelve-percent of patients.
pancreatic acinar cell cystadenocarcinoma	A cystic adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of relatively uniform neoplastic cells which produce pancreatic enzymes and are arranged in acinar patterns. Signs and symptoms include abdominal pain, weight loss, nausea, and diarrhea. It usually has an aggressive clinical course.
cystic partially differentiated kidney nephroblastoma	A variant of Wilms tumor of the kidney characterized by the presence of cystic spaces separated by septa. The septa contain immature epithelial cells, immature stromal cells, and blastema cells. Surgical resection is usually curative.
metanephric stromal tumour	A rare benign renal neoplasm composed of moderately cellular spindle cells. It occurs mostly in infancy and childhood.
gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma	An adenocarcinoma that arises from and straddles the junction of the stomach and esophagus. The category of adenocarcinomas of the gastroesophageal junction also includes the majority of adenocarcinomas previously called gastric cardia adenocarcinomas. Squamous cell carcinomas that affect or cross the junction of the stomach and esophagus are classified as carcinomas of the distal esophagus. Adenocarcinoma of the gastroesophageal junction occurs more often in Caucasian middle aged and elderly males. Clinical signs and symptoms include dysphagia, abdominal pain, and weight loss. The prognosis depends on the completeness of the surgical resection, the number of lymph nodes involved by cancer, and the presence or absence of postoperative complications. The presence of TP53 mutations indicates worse prognosis.
adult renal wilms tumor	Wilms tumor of the kidney which occurs in adults.
adenocarcinoma of ampulla of vater	An invasive carcinoma with glandular differentiation arising from the ampulla of Vater. Signs and symptoms include jaundice, abdominal pain, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss.
ampulla of vater adenosquamous carcinoma	A carcinoma with glandular and squamous differentiation arising from the ampulla of Vater. Signs and symptoms include jaundice, abdominal pain, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss.
ampulla of vater clear cell adenocarcinoma	A carcinoma with glandular differentiation arising from the ampulla of Vater. Morphologically, it is characterized by the presence of glycogen-rich cells with hyperchromatic nuclei.
ampulla of vater invasive intestinal type adenocarcinoma	An invasive adenocarcinoma arising from the ampulla of Vater. Morphologically, it is characterized by the presence of intestinal-type malignant epithelial cells.
ampulla of vater mucinous adenocarcinoma	A carcinoma with glandular differentiation arising from the ampulla of Vater. Morphologically, it is characterized by the presence of mucoid stroma formation.
ampullary signet ring cell carcinoma	An adenocarcinoma arising from the ampulla of Vater. Morphologically, it is characterized by the presence of mucin-containing signet-ring cells.
ampullary small cell carcinoma	An aggressive, high-grade and poorly differentiated carcinoma with neuroendocrine differentiation that arises from the ampulla of Vater and the periampullary region. It is characterized by the presence of malignant small cells.
ampulla of vater squamous cell carcinoma	A carcinoma with squamous differentiation arising from the ampulla of Vater. Signs and symptoms include jaundice, abdominal pain, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss.
ampulla of vater undifferentiated carcinoma	An aggressive carcinoma arising from the ampulla of Vater. Morphologically, it is characterized by the presence of malignant epithelial cells without evidence of glandular or squamous differentiation. Signs and symptoms include jaundice, abdominal pain, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss.
anaplastic renal wilm's tumor	Wilms tumor of the kidney characterized by the presence of nuclear anaplasia. Anaplasia is defined by the presence of all of the following: multipolar polyploid mitotic figures, marked nuclear enlargement, and hyperchromasia. When anaplasia is diffuse, it is associated with an unfavorable clinical outcome.
benign ovarian serous neoplasm	A non-metastasizing neoplasm that arises from the ovary and is characterized by the presence of neoplastic epithelium that resembles the epithelium of the fallopian tube. It includes serous cystadenoma, serous adenofibroma, serous cystadenofibroma, and surface papilloma.
mucoepidermoid carcinoma of the bile duct	A mucoepidermoid carcinoma that arises from the extrahepatic bile ducts.
cecal adenocarcinoma	An adenocarcinoma arising from the cecum. It is more frequently seen in populations with a Western type diet and in patients with a history of chronic inflammatory bowel disease. Histologic variants include mucinous adenocarcinoma, signet ring cell carcinoma, medullary carcinoma, serrated adenocarcinoma, cribriform comedo-type adenocarcinoma, and micropapillary adenocarcinoma.
pediatric choriocarcinoma of ovary	A non-gestational choriocarcinoma that arises from the ovary and occurs in children.
childhood ovarian dysgerminoma	A dysgerminoma that arises from the ovary and occurs in children.
pediatric ovarian embryonal carcinoma	An embryonal carcinoma that arises from the ovary and occurs in children.
pediatric ovarian endodermal sinus neoplasm	A yolk sac tumor that arises from the ovary and occurs in children.
wilms tumor	A Wilms tumor of the kidney which occurs in children.
cloacogenic carcinoma of rectum	A carcinoma that arises from the transitional zone at the junction of the rectum and anus.
pancreatic mucinous noncystic carcinoma	An infiltrating pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, characterized by the presence of malignant cells floating in pools of mucin. It has a more favorable prognosis than the conventional infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma. It often arises in association with intraductal pancreatic mucinous neoplasms and in some cases it may result in the development of pseudomyxoma peritonei.
colonic adenosquamous carcinoma	An unusual colon carcinoma characterized by the presence of glandular and squamous carcinomatous components. The two carcinomatous components may be admixed within the tumor, or the two may appear separately in different areas.
small cell carcinoma of the colon	An aggressive, high-grade, and poorly differentiated carcinoma with neuroendocrine differentiation that arises from the colon. It is characterized by the presence of malignant small cells.
epidermoid carcinoma of the colon	A rare epithelial tumour of the colon arising from squamous cells of the colorectal epithelium without the presence of squamous-lined fistulous tracts or a proximal extension of an anal squamous cell carcinoma. It usually presents with nonspecific symptoms, such as anorexia, weight loss, abdominal pain, changes of bowel habits, haematochezia or melaena. Cases of severe symptomatic hypercalcaemia have been reported.
distal bile duct carcinoma	A carcinoma that arises from the common bile duct distal to the insertion of the cystic duct.
cystadenoma of extrahepatic bile duct	A mucinous cystic neoplasm that arises from the extrahepatic bile ducts.
adenosquamous carcinoma of gallbladder	A carcinoma that arises from the gallbladder. It is characterized by the presence of glandular and squamous malignant epithelial components.
colloidal carcinoma of the gallbladder	An adenocarcinoma that arises from the gallbladder. It is characterized by the presence of extracellular mucin that constitutes more than fifty-percent of the tumor.
signet ring cell carcinoma of gallbladder (diagnosis)	An adenocarcinoma that arises from the gallbladder. It is characterized by the presence of signet ring malignant epithelial cells.
oat cell carcinoma of the gallbladder	An aggressive, high-grade and poorly differentiated carcinoma with neuroendocrine differentiation that arises from the gallbladder. It is characterized by the presence of malignant small cells.
adenosquamous carcinoma of the stomach	A carcinoma that arises from the stomach and is characterized by the presence of malignant cells with glandular and squamous differentiation.
gastric cardia adenocarcinoma	An adenocarcinoma that arises from the gastric cardia. The majority of cases have been reclassified as gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinomas.
papillary adenocarcinoma of stomach	A variant of gastric adenocarcinoma with exophytic growth and elongated finger-like processes lined by cylindrical or cuboidal cells supported by fibrovascular connective tissue cores.
small cell carcinoma of stomach	An aggressive, high-grade and poorly differentiated carcinoma with neuroendocrine differentiation that arises from the stomach. It is characterized by the presence of malignant small cells.
squamous cell carcinoma of stomach	A rare epithelial tumour of the stomach, defined histopathologically as keratinising cell masses with pearl formation, mosaic pattern of cell arrangement, intercellular bridges and high concentrations of sulphydryl or disulphide bonds, arising directly from gastric mucosa, without oesophageal involvement. It is characterised by preferential location in the upper third of the stomach, high probability of lympho vascular and serosal invasion and late onset of clinical symptoms associated with poor prognosis including nonspecific symptoms of abdominal pain, dysphagia, vomiting, melaena or haematochezia, haematemesis and weight loss.
tubular adenocarcinoma of stomach (diagnosis)	A variant of gastric adenocarcinoma characterized by prominent dilated or slit-like tubules.
grade 3 colon adenocarcinoma	A colon adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of a malignant cellular infiltrate with less than 50% glandular formation.
high grade colorectal adenocarcinoma	A colorectal adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of a malignant cellular infiltrate with less than 50% glandular formation.
grade iii rectal adenocarcinoma	A rectal adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of a malignant cellular infiltrate with less than 50% glandular formation.
grade 2 colon adenocarcinoma	A colon adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of a malignant cellular infiltrate with 50-95% glandular formation.
moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma	A colorectal adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of a malignant cellular infiltrate with 50-95% glandular formation.
grade ii rectal adenocarcinoma	A rectal adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of a malignant cellular infiltrate with 50-95% glandular formation.
grade 1 colon adenocarcinoma	A colon adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of a malignant cellular infiltrate with more than 95% glandular formation.
low grade colorectal adenocarcinoma	A colorectal adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of a malignant cellular infiltrate with more than 95% glandular formation.
grade 1 rectal adenocarcinoma	A rectal adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of a malignant cellular infiltrate with more than 95% glandular formation.
helicobacter pylori-related gastric adenocarcinoma	An adenocarcinoma that arises from the gastric mucosa and is caused by persistent infection with Helicobacter pylori.
localized adrenal gland pheochromocytoma	A pheochromocytoma that does not invade surrounding tissues and is confined to the adrenal glands.
gastric mucinous adenocarcinoma	A variant of gastric adenocarcinoma with more than half of the tumor containing extracellular mucinous pools.
peritoneal cystic mesothelioma	A cystic mesothelioma that arises from the peritoneum and usually affects young to middle aged females. Grossly, it presents as a large multiloculated tumor mass, usually in the pelvic peritoneum. Histologically it is characterized by the presence of multiple cysts that are lined by one or more layers of mesothelial cells that do not show atypia. Patients usually present with abdominal or pelvic mass and pain. The clinical course is indolent. The tumor may recur, but transformation to diffuse malignant mesothelioma is rare.
nonanaplastic renal wilm's tumor	Wilms tumor of the kidney characterized by the absence of nuclear anaplasia.
opisthorchis viverrini-related cholangiocarcinoma	A cholangiocarcinoma that has developed following infection with Opisthorchis viverrini.
ovarian papillary cystadenoma	A serous cystadenoma of the ovary characterized by the presence of small papillary projections in the inner surface of the cysts.
ovarian surface papilloma	A benign serous neoplasm characterized by the presence of papillary proliferations on the surface of the ovary.
pancreatic mucoepidermoid carcinoma	A carcinoma that arises from the pancreas showing both ductal and squamous differentiation. The squamous component should represent at least 30% of the malignant cellular infiltrate. The prognosis is usually worse than that of ductal adenocarcinoma.
pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma	A carcinoma occurring almost exclusively in adults that probably arises from the pancreatic duct epithelium. Most pancreatic carcinomas are ductal adenocarcinomas of which about two-thirds involve the head, with the remainder in the body and tail of the pancreas. The patients are usually over 50 years of age. Pain, jaundice, and loss of weight are the most common manifestations. Ductal adenocarcinomas usually grow rapidly and are discovered after they have already spread beyond the pancreas. Grossly, ductal adenocarcinomas are firm and poorly defined masses. Microscopically, most ductal adenocarcinomas are characterized by well-developed glandular structures embedded in a desmoplastic stroma. Ductal adenocarcinomas are fatal in the vast majority of cases (WHO 2000). Check for "https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/intervention/C9120" active clinical trials using this agent. ("http://ncit.nci.nih.gov/ncitbrowser/ConceptReport.jsp?dictionary=NCI%20Thesaurus&code=C9120" NCI Thesaurus)
pancreatic foamy gland adenocarcinoma	A pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of adenocarcinoma cells with foamy cytoplasm.
serous cystadenocarcinoma of the pancreas	A very rare malignant epithelial neoplasm of the pancreas composed of cystic structures lined by glycogen-rich clear cells, associated with local invasiveness often involving the spleen, duodenum and/or stomach and metastatic spread to the liver, peritoneum and/or lymph nodes. Presenting symptoms are variable and usually non-specific and include abdominal and/or flank pain, palpable abdominal mass, upper gastrointestinal bleeding, jaundice or abnormal serum liver enzymes, vomiting, anorexia and/or weight loss.
serous cystadenoma of pancreas	A benign, non-metastasizing cystic epithelial neoplasm arising from the exocrine pancreas. It is composed of glycogen-rich epithelial cells which produce a watery fluid. Signs and symptoms include abdominal mass, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss.
signet ring cell carcinoma of pancreas (diagnosis)	A rare pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma with poor prognosis. It is characterized by the presence of malignant signet ring cells infiltrating the pancreatic parenchyma in an individual cell pattern.
periampullary adenocarcinoma	A cancer that forms near the ampulla of Vater (an enlargement of the ducts from the liver and pancreas where they join and enter the small intestine).
squamous cell carcinoma of rectum (disorder)	A rare epithelial tumour of the rectum, arising from squamous cells in the rectal epithelium, without the presence of squamous-lined fistulous tracts in the rectum or a proximal extension of squamous cell carcinoma of anal or gynaecological origin. The reported symptoms are often nonspecific, such as anorexia, weight loss, lower abdominal pain, rectal bleeding and changes of bowel habits.
signet ring cell stomach adenocarcinoma	A poorly cohesive gastric adenocarcinoma characterized by malignant cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin.
extrahepatic bile duct small cell carcinoma	An aggressive, high-grade and poorly differentiated carcinoma with neuroendocrine differentiation that arises from the extrahepatic bile ducts. It is characterized by the presence of malignant small cells.
small intestinal small cell carcinoma	An aggressive, high-grade, and poorly differentiated carcinoma with neuroendocrine differentiation that arises from the small intestine. It is characterized by the presence of malignant small cells.
ovarian embryonal carcinoma, stage iii	Stage III includes: T3, N0, M0. T3: Tumor involves one or both both ovaries with microscopically confirmed peritoneal metastasis outside pelvis. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)
stage iii ovarian polyembryoma ajcc v6	Stage III includes: T3, N0, M0. T3: Tumor involves one or both both ovaries with microscopically confirmed peritoneal metastasis outside pelvis. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)
yolk sac tumor of ovary stage iii	Stage III includes: T3, N0, M0. T3: Tumor involves one or both both ovaries with microscopically confirmed peritoneal metastasis outside pelvis. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)
stage ii ovarian embryonal carcinoma ajcc v6 and v7	Stage II includes: T2, N0, M0. T2: Tumor involves one or both ovaries with pelvic extension and/or implants. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)
stage ii ovarian polyembryoma	Stage II includes: T2, N0, M0. T2: Tumor involves one or both ovaries with pelvic extension and/or implants. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)
stage ii ovarian yolk sac tumor	Stage II includes: T2, N0, M0. T2: Tumor involves one or both ovaries with pelvic extension and/or implants. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)
stage iv ovarian embryonal carcinoma	Stage IV includes: Any T, Any N, M1. M1: Distant metastasis (excludes peritoneal metastasis). (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)
stage iv ovarian polyembryoma ajcc v7	Stage IV includes: Any T, Any N, M1. M1: Distant metastasis (excludes peritoneal metastasis). (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)
