muscles of abdomen	Muscles forming the ABDOMINAL WALL including RECTUS ABDOMINIS; ABDOMINAL OBLIQUE MUSCLES, transversus abdominis, pyramidalis muscles and quadratus abdominis.
musculus quadratus lumborum	A rectangular-shaped muscle of the posterior abdominal wall that takes its origin from the iliac crest and iliolumbar ligament, and inserts on the last rib and transverse processes of the first four lumbar vertebrae; it functions to flex the vertebral column, and also acts as a muscle of inspiration.
abdominal muscle	Muscles forming the ABDOMINAL WALL including RECTUS ABDOMINIS; ABDOMINAL OBLIQUE MUSCLES, transversus abdominis, pyramidalis muscles and quadratus abdominis.
anterior muscle of abdomen	A muscle located in the anterior aspect of the abdominal wall.
muscle of trunk	Muscle (organ) which is a part of the trunk. Examples: external intercostal muscle, external oblique, levator ani.
set of muscles of abdomen	Muscles forming the ABDOMINAL WALL including RECTUS ABDOMINIS; ABDOMINAL OBLIQUE MUSCLES, transversus abdominis, pyramidalis muscles and quadratus abdominis.
muscle trunk	Muscle (organ) which is a part of the trunk. Examples: external intercostal muscle, external oblique, levator ani.
musculi abdominis	Muscles forming the ABDOMINAL WALL including RECTUS ABDOMINIS; ABDOMINAL OBLIQUE MUSCLES, transversus abdominis, pyramidalis muscles and quadratus abdominis.
quadratus lumborum	A rectangular-shaped muscle of the posterior abdominal wall that takes its origin from the iliac crest and iliolumbar ligament, and inserts on the last rib and transverse processes of the first four lumbar vertebrae; it functions to flex the vertebral column, and also acts as a muscle of inspiration.
muscle of abdomen	Muscles forming the ABDOMINAL WALL including RECTUS ABDOMINIS; ABDOMINAL OBLIQUE MUSCLES, transversus abdominis, pyramidalis muscles and quadratus abdominis.
structure of anterior muscle of abdomen (body structure)	A muscle located in the anterior aspect of the abdominal wall.
muscle of abdomen, nos	Muscles forming the ABDOMINAL WALL including RECTUS ABDOMINIS; ABDOMINAL OBLIQUE MUSCLES, transversus abdominis, pyramidalis muscles and quadratus abdominis.
structure of anterior muscle of abdomen	A muscle located in the anterior aspect of the abdominal wall.
skeletal muscle structure of abdomen (body structure)	Muscles forming the ABDOMINAL WALL including RECTUS ABDOMINIS; ABDOMINAL OBLIQUE MUSCLES, transversus abdominis, pyramidalis muscles and quadratus abdominis.
quadratus lumborum muscle	A rectangular-shaped muscle of the posterior abdominal wall that takes its origin from the iliac crest and iliolumbar ligament, and inserts on the last rib and transverse processes of the first four lumbar vertebrae; it functions to flex the vertebral column, and also acts as a muscle of inspiration.
musculature of abdominal wall	Muscles forming the ABDOMINAL WALL including RECTUS ABDOMINIS; ABDOMINAL OBLIQUE MUSCLES, transversus abdominis, pyramidalis muscles and quadratus abdominis.
muscle of anterior abdominal wall	A muscle located in the anterior aspect of the abdominal wall.
diaphragms, respiratory	The musculofibrous partition that separates the THORACIC CAVITY from the ABDOMINAL CAVITY. Contraction of the diaphragm increases the volume of the thoracic cavity aiding INHALATION.
structure of psoas muscle (body structure)	A powerful flexor of the thigh at the hip joint (psoas major) and a weak flexor of the trunk and lumbar spinal column (psoas minor). Psoas is derived from the Greek "psoa", the plural meaning "muscles of the loin". It is a common site of infection manifesting as abscess (PSOAS ABSCESS). The psoas muscles and their fibers are also used frequently in experiments in muscle physiology.
abdominal wall muscle	Muscles forming the ABDOMINAL WALL including RECTUS ABDOMINIS; ABDOMINAL OBLIQUE MUSCLES, transversus abdominis, pyramidalis muscles and quadratus abdominis.
recti abdominis	A long flat muscle that extends along the whole length of both sides of the abdomen. It flexes the vertebral column, particularly the lumbar portion; it also tenses the anterior abdominal wall and assists in compressing the abdominal contents. It is frequently the site of hematomas. In RECONSTRUCTIVE SURGICAL PROCEDURES it is often used for the creation of MYOCUTANEOUS FLAP. (From Gray's Anatomy, 30th American ed, p491)
abdominals transverse	An anterolateral muscle of the abdomen which attaches to the thoracolumbar fascia, iliac crest, inguinal ligament, and the costal cartilages of the lower ribs, and which continues anteriorly as the transverse abdominis aponeurosis, which inserts into the linea alba, the pubic crest, and the pectineal line.
structure of quadratus lumborum muscle (body structure)	A rectangular-shaped muscle of the posterior abdominal wall that takes its origin from the iliac crest and iliolumbar ligament, and inserts on the last rib and transverse processes of the first four lumbar vertebrae; it functions to flex the vertebral column, and also acts as a muscle of inspiration.
skeletal muscle structure of pelvis	Muscle (organ) which is a part of the pelvis. Examples: levator ani,
abdominal musculature	Muscles forming the ABDOMINAL WALL including RECTUS ABDOMINIS; ABDOMINAL OBLIQUE MUSCLES, transversus abdominis, pyramidalis muscles and quadratus abdominis.
anterior abdominal wall muscle	A muscle located in the anterior aspect of the abdominal wall.
abdomen>abdominal wall	The outer margins of the ABDOMEN, extending from the osteocartilaginous thoracic cage to the PELVIS. Though its major part is muscular, the abdominal wall consists of at least seven layers: the SKIN, subcutaneous fat, deep FASCIA; ABDOMINAL MUSCLES, transversalis fascia, extraperitoneal fat, and the parietal PERITONEUM.
abdominal exercises (regime/therapy)	Facilitating exercise of a client's abdominal muscles for therapeutic effect(s) (for example, to prevent lower back injury). Service is billed in 15-minute increments.
abdominal exercise individual each 15 minutes	Facilitating exercise of a client's abdominal muscles for therapeutic effect(s) (for example, to prevent lower back injury). Service is billed in 15-minute increments.
skeletal muscle structure of abdomen	Muscles forming the ABDOMINAL WALL including RECTUS ABDOMINIS; ABDOMINAL OBLIQUE MUSCLES, transversus abdominis, pyramidalis muscles and quadratus abdominis.
musculature of abdomen	Muscles forming the ABDOMINAL WALL including RECTUS ABDOMINIS; ABDOMINAL OBLIQUE MUSCLES, transversus abdominis, pyramidalis muscles and quadratus abdominis.
psoas muscle	A powerful flexor of the thigh at the hip joint (psoas major) and a weak flexor of the trunk and lumbar spinal column (psoas minor). Psoas is derived from the Greek "psoa", the plural meaning "muscles of the loin". It is a common site of infection manifesting as abscess (PSOAS ABSCESS). The psoas muscles and their fibers are also used frequently in experiments in muscle physiology.
abdominis rectus	A long flat muscle that extends along the whole length of both sides of the abdomen. It flexes the vertebral column, particularly the lumbar portion; it also tenses the anterior abdominal wall and assists in compressing the abdominal contents. It is frequently the site of hematomas. In RECONSTRUCTIVE SURGICAL PROCEDURES it is often used for the creation of MYOCUTANEOUS FLAP. (From Gray's Anatomy, 30th American ed, p491)
transversus abdominis	An anterolateral muscle of the abdomen which attaches to the thoracolumbar fascia, iliac crest, inguinal ligament, and the costal cartilages of the lower ribs, and which continues anteriorly as the transverse abdominis aponeurosis, which inserts into the linea alba, the pubic crest, and the pectineal line.
muscle, abdominal	Muscles forming the ABDOMINAL WALL including RECTUS ABDOMINIS; ABDOMINAL OBLIQUE MUSCLES, transversus abdominis, pyramidalis muscles and quadratus abdominis.
skeletal muscle structure of trunk (body structure)	Muscle (organ) which is a part of the trunk. Examples: external intercostal muscle, external oblique, levator ani.
abdominal muscles	Muscles forming the ABDOMINAL WALL including RECTUS ABDOMINIS; ABDOMINAL OBLIQUE MUSCLES, transversus abdominis, pyramidalis muscles and quadratus abdominis.
abd ex.ndvdl ea.15min	Facilitating exercise of a client's abdominal muscles for therapeutic effect(s) (for example, to prevent lower back injury). Service is billed in 15-minute increments.
abdomen--muscles	Muscles forming the ABDOMINAL WALL including RECTUS ABDOMINIS; ABDOMINAL OBLIQUE MUSCLES, transversus abdominis, pyramidalis muscles and quadratus abdominis.
pelvic floor muscle	The muscles, composed of the levator ani and the coccygeus muscles, that create a division between the pelvic cavity and the perineal region.
deep abdominal muscle	The group of muscles in the torso that are closest to the spine and furthest from the skin such as the psoas muscle and the quadratus lumborum.
superficial abdominal muscle	Any one of the anterior or anterolateral abdominal wall muscles, including the cremaster muscle, pyramidalis muscle, external oblique, internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and rectus abdominis muscles.
anterior abdominal wall musculature	A muscle located in the anterior aspect of the abdominal wall.
muscle	Nonparenchymatous organ that primarily consists of skeletal muscle tissue aggregated into macroscopic fasciculi by connective tissue; together with other muscles, it constitutes the muscular system. Examples: biceps, diaphragm, masseter, right third external intercostal muscle, external oblique, levator ani, serratus anterior.
musculoskeletal system	The MUSCLES, bones (BONE AND BONES), and CARTILAGE of the body.
cdisc send biospecimens terminology	A terminology set that includes concepts relevant to CDISC SEND biospecimens.
cdisc send terminology	The terminology subset that includes terms relevant to the Clinical Data Interchange Standards Consortium (CDISC) Standard for Exchange of Non-clinical Data (SEND) group.
abducent nerves	The 6th cranial nerve which originates in the ABDUCENS NUCLEUS of the PONS and sends motor fibers to the lateral rectus muscles of the EYE. Damage to the nerve or its nucleus disrupts horizontal eye movement control.
cranial nerves	Twelve pairs of nerves that carry general afferent, visceral afferent, special afferent, somatic efferent, and autonomic efferent fibers.
nerve vi, cranial	The 6th cranial nerve which originates in the ABDUCENS NUCLEUS of the PONS and sends motor fibers to the lateral rectus muscles of the EYE. Damage to the nerve or its nucleus disrupts horizontal eye movement control.
peripheral nervous system structure	The nervous system outside of the brain and spinal cord. The peripheral nervous system has autonomic and somatic divisions. The autonomic nervous system includes the enteric, parasympathetic, and sympathetic subdivisions. The somatic nervous system includes the cranial and spinal nerves and their ganglia and the peripheral sensory receptors.
nervi craniales	Twelve pairs of nerves that carry general afferent, visceral afferent, special afferent, somatic efferent, and autonomic efferent fibers.
abductor digiti minimi	The 6th cranial nerve which originates in the ABDUCENS NUCLEUS of the PONS and sends motor fibers to the lateral rectus muscles of the EYE. Damage to the nerve or its nucleus disrupts horizontal eye movement control.
nervous peripheral system	The nervous system outside of the brain and spinal cord. The peripheral nervous system has autonomic and somatic divisions. The autonomic nervous system includes the enteric, parasympathetic, and sympathetic subdivisions. The somatic nervous system includes the cranial and spinal nerves and their ganglia and the peripheral sensory receptors.
traumatic injury of abducens nerve	Skada på abducensnerven (den 6. kranialnerven) genom yttre våld (skallskada, skada i ögonhålan). Sådan skada kan leda till försvagning eller förlamning av ögats sidomuskel (musculus rectus lateralis).

peripheral nervous system	The nervous system outside of the brain and spinal cord. The peripheral nervous system has autonomic and somatic divisions. The somatic nervous system includes the cranial and spinal nerves and their ganglia and the peripheral sensory receptors.
abducent nerve [vi]	The 6th cranial nerve which originates in the ABDUCENS NUCLEUS of the PONS and sends motor fibers to the lateral rectus muscles of the EYE. Damage to the nerve or its nucleus disrupts horizontal eye movement control.
lateral rectus muscle structure	A muscle attaching to the lateral surface of the orbit that abducts the eye.
nerve vi	The 6th cranial nerve which originates in the ABDUCENS NUCLEUS of the PONS and sends motor fibers to the lateral rectus muscles of the EYE. Damage to the nerve or its nucleus disrupts horizontal eye movement control.
pons cerebelli	The front part of the hindbrain (RHOMBENCEPHALON) that lies between the MEDULLA and the midbrain (MESENCEPHALON) ventral to the cerebellum. It is composed of two parts, the dorsal and the ventral. The pons serves as a relay station for neural pathways between the CEREBELLUM to the CEREBRUM.
abducens nerve	The 6th cranial nerve which originates in the ABDUCENS NUCLEUS of the PONS and sends motor fibers to the lateral rectus muscles of the EYE. Damage to the nerve or its nucleus disrupts horizontal eye movement control.
cranial nerve structure (body structure)	Twelve pairs of nerves that carry general afferent, visceral afferent, special afferent, somatic efferent, and autonomic efferent fibers.
nervus abducen	The 6th cranial nerve which originates in the ABDUCENS NUCLEUS of the PONS and sends motor fibers to the lateral rectus muscles of the EYE. Damage to the nerve or its nucleus disrupts horizontal eye movement control.
visual structure	The eye, ocular adnexa, afferent visual pathways, efferent visual pathways, and pupil innervation pathways
cranial nerve vi	The 6th cranial nerve which originates in the ABDUCENS NUCLEUS of the PONS and sends motor fibers to the lateral rectus muscles of the EYE. Damage to the nerve or its nucleus disrupts horizontal eye movement control.
visual structure (body structure)	The eye, ocular adnexa, afferent visual pathways, efferent visual pathways, and pupil innervation pathways
abducens nerve structure (body structure)	The 6th cranial nerve which originates in the ABDUCENS NUCLEUS of the PONS and sends motor fibers to the lateral rectus muscles of the EYE. Damage to the nerve or its nucleus disrupts horizontal eye movement control.
duane's syndrome	Soubor příznaků vzácné vrozené poruchy motility očních bulbů, někdy na podkladě AD dědičnosti, v některých případech vyskytující se sdruženě s jinými anomáliemi. Onemocnění spočívá v anomální inervaci mediálního a laterálního přímého očního svalu vedoucí k nedostatečné kontrakci při addukci bulbu. Při pokusu o addukci je často bulbus stáčen nahoru nebo dolů. Vada se může projevit esotropií, exotropií nebo jsou bulby relativně ve správném postavení při přímém pohledu. V některých případech se rozvíjí amblyopie. Léčba je chirurgická. (cit. Velký lékařský slovník online, 2018 http://lekarske.slovniky.cz)
nervus abducens [vi]	The 6th cranial nerve which originates in the ABDUCENS NUCLEUS of the PONS and sends motor fibers to the lateral rectus muscles of the EYE. Damage to the nerve or its nucleus disrupts horizontal eye movement control.
tolosa-hunt syndrome	An idiopathic syndrome characterized by the formation of granulation tissue in the anterior cavernous sinus or superior orbital fissure, producing a painful ophthalmoplegia. (Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, p271)
lateral rectus nerve	The 6th cranial nerve which originates in the ABDUCENS NUCLEUS of the PONS and sends motor fibers to the lateral rectus muscles of the EYE. Damage to the nerve or its nucleus disrupts horizontal eye movement control.

traumatic abducens nerve injury	Skada på abducensnerven (den 6. kranialnerven) genom yttre våld (skallskada, skada i ögonhålan). Sådan skada kan leda till försvagning eller förlamning av ögats sidomuskel (musculus rectus lateralis).
nerve vis	The 6th cranial nerve which originates in the ABDUCENS NUCLEUS of the PONS and sends motor fibers to the lateral rectus muscles of the EYE. Damage to the nerve or its nucleus disrupts horizontal eye movement control.
injury of abducent nerve	Skada på abducensnerven (den 6. kranialnerven) genom yttre våld (skallskada, skada i ögonhålan). Sådan skada kan leda till försvagning eller förlamning av ögats sidomuskel (musculus rectus lateralis).
mobius syndrome	A syndrome of congenital facial paralysis, frequently associated with abducens palsy and other congenital abnormalities including lingual palsy, clubfeet, brachial disorders, cognitive deficits, and pectoral muscle defects. Pathologic findings are variable and include brain stem nuclear aplasia, facial nerve aplasia, and facial muscle aplasia, consistent with a multifactorial etiology. (Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, p1020)
abducens nerve dis	Sjukdomar i den 6. kranialnerven (abducens) eller dess kärna i hjärnbryggan (pons). Defekter hos nerven orsakar svaghet i ögats sidomuskel (musculus rectus lateralis), vilken leder till horisontellt d ubbelseende och skelning (esotropi). Vanliga orsaker till nervskada är högt intrakraniellt blodtryck, skallskador, ischemi eller infratentoriella tumörer.
6n	The 6th cranial nerve which originates in the ABDUCENS NUCLEUS of the PONS and sends motor fibers to the lateral rectus muscles of the EYE. Damage to the nerve or its nucleus disrupts horizontal eye movement control.
sixth cranial nerve disease (disorder)	Sjukdomar i den 6. kranialnerven (abducens) eller dess kärna i hjärnbryggan (pons). Defekter hos nerven orsakar svaghet i ögats sidomuskel (musculus rectus lateralis), vilken leder till horisontellt d ubbelseende och skelning (esotropi). Vanliga orsaker till nervskada är högt intrakraniellt blodtryck, skallskador, ischemi eller infratentoriella tumörer.
nerve, abducens	The 6th cranial nerve which originates in the ABDUCENS NUCLEUS of the PONS and sends motor fibers to the lateral rectus muscles of the EYE. Damage to the nerve or its nucleus disrupts horizontal eye movement control.
raymond-cestan syndrome	Abducent nerve paralysis with contralateral hemiparesis
duane-radial ray syndrome	A syndrome consisting of Duane's syndrome, radial ray anomaly, and frequently, HEARING LOSS, SENSORINEURAL.
duane anomaly, myopathy, scoliosis syndrome (disorder)	Syndrome with the association of bilateral Duane anomaly type 3, severe scoliosis of early onset, congenital myopathy with hypotonia without muscular weakness, delayed motor development, and short stature. It has been described in one pair of siblings. The Duane type 3 anomaly consists of eye abduction and adduction palsy, globe retraction and narrowing of the palpebral fissure. Muscular biopsy shows aspecific myopathy. Intellectual development is normal. The syndrome is most likely inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.
palsy, abducens	Malfunction of the abducens nerve as manifested by impairment of the ability of the affected eye to be moved outward. Patients who develop abducens nerve palsy often present with binocular horizontal diplopia, which is a double vision when looking at objects side by side. There will be a notable weakness of the ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle leading to a deficit in of eye abduction on the affected side. Some patients may present with a constant head turning movement to maintain binocular fusion and to lessen the degree of diplopia. [PMID:29489275]
abducent nerve paralysis	Malfunction of the abducens nerve as manifested by impairment of the ability of the affected eye to be moved outward. Patients who develop abducens nerve palsy often present with binocular horizontal diplopia, which is a double vision when looking at objects side by side. There will be a notable weakness of the ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle leading to a deficit in of eye abduction on the affected side. Some patients may present with a constant head turning movement to maintain binocular fusion and to lessen the degree of diplopia. [PMID:29489275]
cranial nerve vis	The 6th cranial nerve which originates in the ABDUCENS NUCLEUS of the PONS and sends motor fibers to the lateral rectus muscles of the EYE. Damage to the nerve or its nucleus disrupts horizontal eye movement control.

Onemocnění spočívá v anomální inervaci mediálního a laterálního přímého očního svalu vedoucí k nedostatečné kontrakci při addukci bulbu. Při pokusu o addukci je často bulbus stáčen nahoru nebo dolů. Vada se může projevit esotropií, exotropií nebo jsou bulby relativně ve správném postavení při přímém pohledu. V některých případech se rozvíjí amblyopie. Léčba je chirurgická. (cit. abducens nerve injury	Skada på abducensnerven (den 6. kranialnerven) genom yttre våld (skallskada, skada i ögonhålan). Sådan skada kan leda till försvagning eller förlamning av ögats sidomuskel (musculus rectus lateralis).
nerve traumas, abducens	Skada på abducensnerven (den 6. kranialnerven) genom yttre våld (skallskada, skada i ögonhålan). Sådan skada kan leda till försvagning eller förlamning av ögats sidomuskel (musculus rectus lateralis).
moebius; congenital oculofacial paralysis	A syndrome of congenital facial paralysis, frequently associated with abducens palsy and other congenital abnormalities including lingual palsy, clubfeet, brachial disorders, cognitive deficits, and pectoral muscle defects. Pathologic findings are variable and include brain stem nuclear aplasia, facial nerve aplasia, and facial muscle aplasia, consistent with a multifactorial etiology. (Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, p1020)
abducens nerve weakness	Sjukdomar i den 6. kranialnerven (abducens) eller dess kärna i hjärnbryggan (pons). Defekter hos nerven orsakar svaghet i ögats sidomuskel (musculus rectus lateralis), vilken leder till horisontellt d ubbelseende och skelning (esotropi). Vanliga orsaker till nervskada är högt intrakraniellt blodtryck, skallskador, ischemi eller infratentoriella tumörer.
disorder of abducent nerve	Sjukdomar i den 6. kranialnerven (abducens) eller dess kärna i hjärnbryggan (pons). Defekter hos nerven orsakar svaghet i ögats sidomuskel (musculus rectus lateralis), vilken leder till horisontellt d ubbelseende och skelning (esotropi). raymond-cestan syndrome (disorder)	Abducent nerve paralysis with contralateral hemiparesis
acrorenoocular syndrome	A syndrome consisting of Duane's syndrome, radial ray anomaly, and frequently, HEARING LOSS, SENSORINEURAL.
abducence nerve	The 6th cranial nerve which originates in the ABDUCENS NUCLEUS of the PONS and sends motor fibers to the lateral rectus muscles of the EYE. Damage to the nerve or its nucleus disrupts horizontal eye movement control.
abducens nerve paralysis	Malfunction of the abducens nerve as manifested by impairment of the ability of the affected eye to be moved outward. Patients who develop abducens nerve palsy often present with binocular horizontal diplopia, which is a double vision when looking at objects side by side. There will be a notable weakness of the ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle leading to a deficit in of eye abduction on the affected side. Some patients may present with a constant head turning movement to maintain binocular fusion and to lessen the degree of diplopia. [PMID:29489275]

nervus cranialis	Twelve pairs of nerves that carry general afferent, visceral afferent, special afferent, somatic efferent, and autonomic efferent fibers.
cranium	The SKELETON of the HEAD including the FACIAL BONES and the bones enclosing the BRAIN.
abducens nucleus	A region in the PONTINE TEGMENTUM that is the nucleus of the ABDUCENS NERVE.
vith nerve disorder	Sjukdomar i den 6. kranialnerven (abducens) eller dess kärna i hjärnbryggan (pons). sdtm	The terminology subset that includes terms pertaining to the CDISC Study Data Tabulation Model (SDTM).
clinical data interchange standards consortium terminology	The terminology that includes terms relevant to the Clinical Data Interchange Standards Consortium.
anatomical location	Terminology codelist used with Anatomical Locations within the Clinical Data Interchange Standards Consortium Study Data Tabulation Model.
abducens nerve paresis	Malfunction of the abducens nerve as manifested by impairment of the ability of the affected eye to be moved outward. Patients who develop abducens nerve palsy often present with binocular horizontal diplopia, which is a double vision when looking at objects side by side. There will be a notable weakness of the ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle leading to a deficit in of eye abduction on the affected side. Some patients may present with a constant head turning movement to maintain binocular fusion and to lessen the degree of diplopia. [PMID:29489275]
abelson murine leukemia virus	Ett defekt musleukemivirus med förmåga att transformera lymfceller och åstadkomma hastigt fortskridande lymfoid leukemi, efter superinfektion med Friend-, Moloney- eller Rauschervirus.
murine leukemia virus	Species of GAMMARETROVIRUS, containing many well-defined strains, producing leukemia in mice. Disease is commonly induced by injecting filtrates of propagable tumors into newborn mice.
a-mulv	Ett defekt musleukemivirus med förmåga att transformera lymfceller och åstadkomma hastigt fortskridande lymfoid leukemi, efter superinfektion med Friend-, Moloney- eller Rauschervirus.
v-abl genes	V-ABL is an ABL oncogene of Abelson's murine leukemia virus.
abetalipoproteinemia	An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.
hypo-beta-lipoproteinemia (disorder)	Conditions with abnormally low levels of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL) in the blood. It is defined as LDL values equal to or less than the 5th percentile for the population. They include the autosomal dominant form involving mutation of the APOLIPOPROTEINS B gene, and the autosomal recessive form involving mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein. All are characterized by low LDL and dietary fat malabsorption.
microsomal triglyceride transfer protein defic	An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.
spur cell anaemia	Acanthocytosis is a type of poikilocytosis characterized by the presence of spikes on the cell surface. The cells have an irregular shape resembling many-pointed stars. [HPO:probinson]
abl - abetalipoproteinaemia	An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.
ataxia	Impairment of the ability to perform smoothly coordinated voluntary movements. This condition may affect the limbs, trunk, eyes, pharynx, larynx, and other structures. Ataxia may result from impaired sensory or motor function. Sensory ataxia may result from posterior column injury or PERIPHERAL NERVE DISEASES. Motor ataxia may be associated with CEREBELLAR DISEASES; CEREBRAL CORTEX diseases; THALAMIC DISEASES; BASAL GANGLIA DISEASES; injury to the RED NUCLEUS; and other conditions.
microsomal triglyceride transfer protein deficiency	An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.
myelinoclasis	Breakdown, or abnormal development, of a nerve fiber myelin sheath.
bassen kornzweig syndrome	An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.
retinal disease	Diseases involving the RETINA.
abetalipoproteinaemia	An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.
autosomal recessive inheritance	Autosomal recessive inheritance refers to genetic conditions that occur only when mutations are present in both copies of a given gene (i.e., the person is homozygous for a mutation, or carries two different mutations of the same gene, a state referred to as compound heterozygosity).
bassen-kornzweig syndrome	An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.
fat malabsorption	Abnormality of the absorption of fat from the gastrointestinal tract. [HPO:probinson]
acanthocytosis	Acanthocytosis is a type of poikilocytosis characterized by the presence of spikes on the cell surface. The cells have an irregular shape resembling many-pointed stars. [HPO:probinson]
microsomal triglyceride transfer protein deficiency disease	An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.
rndx metabolic	Generic term for diseases caused by an abnormal metabolic process. It can be congenital due to inherited enzyme abnormality (METABOLISM, INBORN ERRORS) or acquired due to disease of an endocrine organ or failure of a metabolically important organ such as the liver. (Stedman, 26th ed)
abetalipoproteinemia (disorder)	An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.
disorder of lipid metabolism	Pathological conditions resulting from abnormal anabolism or catabolism of lipids in the body.
acanthocytoses	An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.
rare non-neoplastic disorder	A non-neoplastic disorder that is rare.
cellosaurus disease terminology	CELLOSAURUS is a knowledge resource on cell lines. It attempts to describe all cell lines used in biomedical research. It includes immortalized cell lines; naturally immortal cell lines (such as stem cell lines); finite life cell lines when those are distributed and used widely. It encompasses vertebrate cell lines, with an emphasis on human, mouse and rat cell lines, and invertebrate (insects and ticks) cell lines. The Cellosaurus disease terminology is the set of terms used to annotate cell lines originating from a diseased patient or animal. For inherited diseases, the relevant terms are only applied to cell lines originating from individuals suffering or at risk for a disease and not for individuals that are carriers for such disease. For cancers, the relevant terms are only applied to cell lines established from a cancerous tissue. The Cellosaurus (https://web.expasy.org/cellosaurus/) is developed by Dr. Amos Bairoch of the CALIPHO group (https://www.sib.swiss/amos-bairoch-lydie-lane-group) at the Swiss Institute of Bioinformatics (https://www.sib.swiss).
ldl low	An decreased concentration of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood. [HPO:gcarletti]
lipoprotein deficiency	presence of abnormally low levels of lipoproteins in the serum.
hypolipoproteinemia	presence of abnormally low levels of lipoproteins in the serum.
body system	Anatomical structure, which consists of members of predominantly one organ subclass; these members are interconnected by zones of continuity. Examples: skeletal system, cardiovascular system, alimentary system.
bassen kornzweig disease	An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.
congenital	Denoting something that is present at birth.
diseases, betalipoprotein deficiency	An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.
congenital, familial and genetic disorders (smq)	This SMQ is a sub-search of SMQ Pregnancy and neonatal topics. For detailed description, please refer to the one in SMQ Pregnancy and neonatal topics.
deficiency diseases, betalipoprotein	An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.
bassen-kornzweig	An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.
abl - abetalipoproteinemia	An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.
bassen kornzweig dis	An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.
microsomal triglyceride transfer protein defic dis	An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.
lipoprotein deficiency disorder	presence of abnormally low levels of lipoproteins in the serum.
disorders of lipid metabolism	Pathological conditions resulting from abnormal anabolism or catabolism of lipids in the body.
abl	An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.
lipoprotein; deficiency	presence of abnormally low levels of lipoproteins in the serum.
fat disorder	Pathological conditions resulting from abnormal anabolism or catabolism of lipids in the body.
hypolipoproteinaemia (disorder)	presence of abnormally low levels of lipoproteins in the serum.
bassen-kornzweig disease	An autosomal recessive disorder of lipid metabolism. It is caused by mutation of the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein that catalyzes the transport of lipids (TRIGLYCERIDES; CHOLESTEROL ESTERS; PHOSPHOLIPIDS) and is required in the secretion of BETA-LIPOPROTEINS (low density lipoproteins or LDL). Features include defective intestinal lipid absorption, very low serum cholesterol level, and near absent LDL.
malformation	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
hereditary disease	general term for any disorder caused by a genetic mechanism, comprising chromosome aberrations or anomalies, mendelian or monogenic or single-gene disorders, and multifactorial disorders; note that all genetic disorders are not treed under this term; see RTs for others; in addition, many disorders not treed here or under RTs may have a genetic component.
congenital deformity	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
anatomic abnormality	An anatomic abnormality that is either present at birth or appears later in life.
congenital abnormality	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
teratogenesis	The result of processes that negatively affect a developing fetus.
congenital anomaly nos	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
congenital or acquired anatomic abnormality	An anatomic abnormality that is either present at birth or appears later in life.
developmental disturbance	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
congenital anomaly	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
fetal disorders (smq)	SMQ Pregnancy and neonatal topics was developed to replace original SMQ Adverse pregnancy outcome/reproductive toxicity (incl neonatal disorders) which had discrepancies in term inclusion resulting in maintenance issues. It was also developed to be more compatible with regulatory goals related to pregnancy and neonatal topics. Lactation associated disorders (functional and related to neonatal exposures through breast milk) are also in this SMQ, but fertility-related topics and developmental disorders are not. Referenced during construction of this SMQ was EMA's Guideline on the Exposure to Medicinal Products during Pregnancy: Need for Post-Authorisation Data in which pregnancy outcomes are defined as: Live birth, normal; Live birth, abnormal (including pre-term, term, and post-term birth; small for gestational age infants/ Intrauterine growth retardation; drug withdrawal syndrome in the neonate; malformations; and morbidity); Fetal death (including ectopic, miscarriage and stillbirth); and Termination of pregnancy. Sub-search SMQ Foetal disorders relates to issues concerning the condition of the fetus.
congenital deformity, nos	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
congenital anomaly nos (disorder)	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
congenital defect	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
scong	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.

defects, congenital	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.

developmental defect, nos	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
foetal developmental abnormality	existing at, and usually before, birth; referring to conditions that are present at birth, regardless of their causation; inborn metabolism disorders are generally not treed here.
congenital deformity (morphologic abnormality)	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
foetal disorders (smq)	SMQ Pregnancy and neonatal topics was developed to replace original SMQ Adverse pregnancy outcome/reproductive toxicity (incl neonatal disorders) which had discrepancies in term inclusion resulting in maintenance issues. It was also developed to be more compatible with regulatory goals related to pregnancy and neonatal topics. Lactation associated disorders (functional and related to neonatal exposures through breast milk) are also in this SMQ, but fertility-related topics and developmental disorders are not. Referenced during construction of this SMQ was EMA's Guideline on the Exposure to Medicinal Products during Pregnancy: Need for Post-Authorisation Data in which pregnancy outcomes are defined as: Live birth, normal; Live birth, abnormal (including pre-term, term, and post-term birth; small for gestational age infants/ Intrauterine growth retardation; drug withdrawal syndrome in the neonate; malformations; and morbidity); Fetal death (including ectopic, miscarriage and stillbirth); and Termination of pregnancy. Sub-search SMQ Foetal disorders relates to issues concerning the condition of the fetus.
congenital disorder (disorder)	existing at, and usually before, birth; referring to conditions that are present at birth, regardless of their causation; inborn metabolism disorders are generally not treed here.
anomaly anomaly congen	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
prostaglandin pge<sub>1</sub> (substance)	A potent vasodilator agent that increases peripheral blood flow.
imperforate hymen	A congenital disorder where the hymen (a membrane that surrounds or partially covers the external vaginal opening) does not have an opening and completely obstructs the vagina. [PMID:24822139]
sprengel deformity	A congenital skeletal deformity characterized by the elevation of one scapula (thus, one scapula is located superior to the other). [HPO:probinson]
abnormalities	Užij u orgánů pro vrozené defekty způsobující změny v morfologii orgánu; užij také pro abnormality u zvířat.
arrhinia	Complete absence of all nasal structures. [HPO:probinson]
congenital absence of gallbladder (disorder)	A developmental defect in which the gallbladder fails to form. [DDD:hfirth]
deformity	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
renal agenesis, bilateral	A congenital abnormality characterized by the absence of both kidneys.
foetal malformation	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
congenital cleft larynx (disorder)	A rare congenital abnormality in the laryngo-tracheal wall. It results from the incomplete development of the tracheoesophageal septum. Signs and symptoms include coughing, cyanosis, repeated pulmonary infections, and failure to gain weight.
congenital defects	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
saito kuba tsuruta syndrome	This syndrome has features of fibuloulnar dysostosis with renal anomalies. It has been described in two siblings born to nonconsanguinous parents. The syndrome is lethal at birth (respiratory failure). Clinical manifestations include ear and facial anomalies (including micrognathia), symmetrical shortness of long bones, fibular agenesis and hypoplastic ulna, oligosyndactyly, congenital heart defects, and cystic or hypoplastic kidney. It is transmitted as an autosomal recessive trait.
birth defect	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
cleft lip-palate, agenesis of clavicles and cervical vertebrae, and talipes equinovarus	A very rare syndrome characterised by poorly mineralised calvarium, facial dysmorphism, vertebral abnormalities and absent clavicles. Nine cases have been reported in the literature so far. Dysmorphic features include micrognathia, cleft palate, hypertelorism and upturned nares. Clavicular aplasia is constant and agenesis of cervical vertebral bodies is frequent. Intra uterine growth retardation is constant. It is most likely that the condition is hereditary, transmitted as an autosomal recessive trait. Prognosis is poor, the syndrome is almost always lethal soon after birth.
dysgenesis, nos	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
patterson stevenson fontaine syndrome	Features the presence of a usually opposable triphalangeal thumb with or without additional duplication of one or more skeletal components of the thumb. The thumb appearance can differ widely in shape (wedge to rectangular) or it can be deviated in the radio-ulnar plane. Also associated with systemic syndromes including Holt-Oram syndrome.
bresek syndrome	X-linked mental retardation with characteristics of Brain anomalies, severe mental Retardation, Ectodermal dysplasia, Skeletal deformities (vertebral anomalies, scoliosis, polydactyly), Ear/eye anomalies (maldevelopment, small optic nerves, low set and large ears with hearing loss) and Kidney dysplasia/hypoplasia (giving the acronym BRESEK syndrome). It has been described in two brothers, one of whom died shortly after birth. One of the brothers also had Hirschsprung disease and Cleft palate/cryptorchidism (giving the acronym: BRESHECK syndrome). Transmission is X-linked dominant.
disorder birth	existing at, and usually before, birth; referring to conditions that are present at birth, regardless of their causation; inborn metabolism disorders are generally not treed here.
birth defects	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
hereditary diseases	general term for any disorder caused by a genetic mechanism, comprising chromosome aberrations or anomalies, mendelian or monogenic or single-gene disorders, and multifactorial disorders; note that all genetic disorders are not treed under this term; see RTs for others; in addition, many disorders not treed here or under RTs may have a genetic component.
postnatal growth disorder	physical growth disorders occurring after birth.
developmental abnormality	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
drug ind abnorm	Congenital abnormalities caused by medicinal substances or drugs of abuse given to or taken by the mother, or to which she is inadvertently exposed during the manufacture of such substances. The concept excludes abnormalities resulting from exposure to non-medicinal chemicals in the environment.
anomaly; musculoskeletal	Congenital structural abnormalities and deformities of the musculoskeletal system.
congenital malformation syndrome (disorder)	A syndrome characterized by the presence of congenital abnormalities that affect more than one organ or system.
congenital qualifier	Denoting something that is present at birth.
dysmorphism	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.

congenital disorders	existing at, and usually before, birth; referring to conditions that are present at birth, regardless of their causation; inborn metabolism disorders are generally not treed here.
at birth	Denoting something that is present at birth.
congenital malformation, nos	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
malformations multiple	Congenital abnormalities that affect more than one organ or body structure.
albinism (physical finding)	General term for a number of inherited defects of amino acid metabolism in which there is a deficiency or absence of pigment in the eyes, skin, or hair.
congenital malformations	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
chromosomal disorders	clinical conditions caused by an abnormal chromosome constitution in which there is extra or missing chromosome material, either a whole chromosome or a chromosome segment.
congenital respiratory tract malformation	Congenital structural abnormalities of the respiratory system.
congenital defect/deformity	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
congenital musculoskeletal deformity	Congenital structural abnormalities and deformities of the musculoskeletal system.
limb deformities congen	Congenital structural deformities of the upper and lower extremities collectively or unspecified.
neck; deformity, congenital	An abnormality of the neck. [HPO:probinson]
congenital anomaly;nerv sys	Strukturella missbildningar i det centrala eller perifera nervsystemet, främst till följd av defekt embryogenes.
congenital anomaly of cardiovascular system (disorder)	A heart or vascular abnormality which is inborn or present at birth.
anomalous formation, nos	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
birth disorders	existing at, and usually before, birth; referring to conditions that are present at birth, regardless of their causation; inborn metabolism disorders are generally not treed here.
congen defects	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
defect, congenital	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
heterotopias	A mass of histologically normal tissue present in an abnormal location.
univentricular heart	An umbrella term used to describe several very different complex congenital heart defects that share the same problem: the heart has only one functional ventricle (anatomically right or left or indeterminate) supplying the systemic circulation. These defects include tricuspid atresia, hypoplastic left or right heart syndrome, double outlet right ventricle, double inlet left ventricle, and other forms of single ventricle defects.
congenital dysplasia	Abnormal tissue formation due to abnormal cellular organization, which may result in a morphologic defect.
congenital failure of fusion	congenital defects of closure of one or more vertebral arches, which may be associated with malformations of the spinal cord, nerve roots, congenital fibrous bands, lipomas, and congenital cysts.
vascular malformation	A congenital abnormality of the arteries and veins, lymph vessels or veins and lymph vessels.
abnormality, congenital	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
amniotic band syndrome	A disorder present in the newborn infant in which constriction rings or bands, causing soft tissue depressions, encircle digits, extremities, or limbs and sometimes the neck, thorax, or abdomen. They may be associated with intrauterine amputations.
chiari malformation	En medfödd missbildning, där lillhjärnan och den förlängda märgen löper ner i ryggmärgskanalen genom foramen magnum. Missbildningen kan vara förenad med andra defekter, såsom spina bifida occulta och meningomyelocele (ryggmärgsbråck). Missbildningen indelas i olika typer, typ I, typ II (den vanligaste, med hoptryckning av märgen och lillhjärnstonsillerna i kombination med meningomyelocele), typ II I och typ IV.
arteriovenous malformation (morphologic abnormality)	Abnormal formation of blood vessels that shunt arterial blood directly into veins without passing through the CAPILLARIES. They usually are crooked, dilated, and with thick vessel walls. A common type is the congenital arteriovenous fistula. The lack of blood flow and oxygen in the capillaries can lead to tissue damage in the affected areas.
arthrogryposis, congenital multiple	Persistent flexure or contracture of a joint.
amyoplasia congen	Persistent flexure or contracture of a joint.
at, complementation group d	An autosomal recessive inherited disorder characterized by choreoathetosis beginning in childhood, progressive CEREBELLAR ATAXIA; TELANGIECTASIS of CONJUNCTIVA and SKIN; DYSARTHRIA; B- and T-cell immunodeficiency, and RADIOSENSITIVITY to IONIZING RADIATION. Affected individuals are prone to recurrent sinobronchopulmonary infections, lymphoreticular neoplasms, and other malignancies. Serum ALPHA-FETOPROTEINS are usually elevated. (Menkes, Textbook of Child Neurology, 5th ed, p688) The gene for this disorder (ATM) encodes a cell cycle checkpoint protein kinase and has been mapped to chromosome 11 (11q22-q23).
beckwith-wiedemann syndrome	A syndrome of multiple defects characterized primarily by umbilical hernia (HERNIA, UMBILICAL); MACROGLOSSIA; and GIGANTISM; and secondarily by visceromegaly; HYPOGLYCEMIA; and ear abnormalities.
bladder exstrophy	A birth defect in which the URINARY BLADDER is malformed and exposed, inside out, and protruded through the ABDOMINAL WALL. It is caused by closure defects involving the top front surface of the bladder, as well as the lower abdominal wall; SKIN; MUSCLES; and the pubic bone.
ectopia vesicae	A birth defect in which the URINARY BLADDER is malformed and exposed, inside out, and protruded through the ABDOMINAL WALL. It is caused by closure defects involving the top front surface of the bladder, as well as the lower abdominal wall; SKIN; MUSCLES; and the pubic bone.
abnormal development	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
bloom's syndrome (diagnosis)	An autosomal recessive disorder characterized by telangiectatic ERYTHEMA of the face, photosensitivity, DWARFISM and other abnormalities, and a predisposition toward developing cancer. The Bloom syndrome gene (BLM) encodes a RecQ-like DNA helicase.
congenital atresia of choana	A congenital abnormality that is characterized by a blocked CHOANAE, the opening between the nose and the NASOPHARYNX. Blockage can be unilateral or bilateral; bony or membranous.
choanal atresia	A congenital abnormality that is characterized by a blocked CHOANAE, the opening between the nose and the NASOPHARYNX. Blockage can be unilateral or bilateral; bony or membranous.
developmental defect	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
ciliary dyskinesias	Conditions caused by abnormal CILIA movement in the body, usually causing KARTAGENER SYNDROME, chronic respiratory disorders, chronic SINUSITIS, and chronic OTITIS. Abnormal ciliary beating is likely due to defects in any of the 200 plus ciliary proteins, such as missing motor enzyme DYNEIN arms.
hare lip	Congenital defect in the upper lip where the maxillary prominence fails to merge with the merged medial nasal prominences. It is thought to be caused by faulty migration of the mesoderm in the head region.
congenital malformation, unspecified	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
congenital fissure of lip	Congenital defect in the upper lip where the maxillary prominence fails to merge with the merged medial nasal prominences. It is thought to be caused by faulty migration of the mesoderm in the head region.
cleft upper lip	Congenital defect in the upper lip where the maxillary prominence fails to merge with the merged medial nasal prominences. It is thought to be caused by faulty migration of the mesoderm in the head region.
cleft-palate	Congenital fissure of the soft and/or hard palate, due to faulty fusion.
cleft palate	Congenital fissure of the soft and/or hard palate, due to faulty fusion.
palates, cleft	Congenital fissure of the soft and/or hard palate, due to faulty fusion.
palatoschisis	Congenital fissure of the soft and/or hard palate, due to faulty fusion.
dysostosis; cleidocranial	Autosomal dominant syndrome in which there is delayed closing of the CRANIAL FONTANELLES; complete or partial absence of the collarbones (CLAVICLES); wide PUBIC SYMPHYSIS; short middle phalanges of the fifth fingers; and dental and vertebral anomalies.
cleidocranial dysostosis	Autosomal dominant syndrome in which there is delayed closing of the CRANIAL FONTANELLES; complete or partial absence of the collarbones (CLAVICLES); wide PUBIC SYMPHYSIS; short middle phalanges of the fifth fingers; and dental and vertebral anomalies.
cockayne syndrome	A syndrome characterized by multiple system abnormalities including DWARFISM; PHOTOSENSITIVITY DISORDERS; PREMATURE AGING; and HEARING LOSS. It is caused by mutations of a number of autosomal recessive genes encoding proteins that involve transcriptional-coupled DNA REPAIR processes. Cockayne syndrome is classified by the severity and age of onset. Type I (classical; CSA) is early childhood onset in the second year of life; type II (congenital; CSB) is early onset at birth with severe symptoms; type III (xeroderma pigmentosum; XP) is late childhood onset with mild symptoms.
congenital anomaly (disorder)	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
cryptorchidism nos	A developmental defect in which a TESTIS or both TESTES failed to descend from high in the ABDOMEN to the bottom of the SCROTUM. Testicular descent is essential to normal SPERMATOGENESIS which requires temperature lower than the BODY TEMPERATURE. Cryptorchidism can be subclassified by the location of the maldescended testis.
cryptorchidism	A developmental defect in which a TESTIS or both TESTES failed to descend from high in the ABDOMEN to the bottom of the SCROTUM. Testicular descent is essential to normal SPERMATOGENESIS which requires temperature lower than the BODY TEMPERATURE. Cryptorchidism can be subclassified by the location of the maldescended testis.
congenital abnormalities	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
undescended testis	A developmental defect in which a TESTIS or both TESTES failed to descend from high in the ABDOMEN to the bottom of the SCROTUM. Testicular descent is essential to normal SPERMATOGENESIS which requires temperature lower than the BODY TEMPERATURE. Cryptorchidism can be subclassified by the location of the maldescended testis.
dens in dente	Anomaly of the tooth, found chiefly in upper lateral incisors. It is characterized by invagination of the enamel at the incisal edge.
congenital malformation (disorder)	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
dentin dysplasia (disorder)	An apparently hereditary disorder of dentin formation, marked by a normal appearance of coronal dentin associated with pulpal obliteration, faulty root formation, and a tendency for peripheral lesions without obvious cause. (From Dorland, 27th ed)
defect/deformity, congenital	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
dentinogenesis imperfecta	An autosomal dominant disorder of tooth development characterized by opalescent dentin resulting in discoloration of the teeth. The dentin develops poorly with low mineral content while the pulp canal is obliterated.
congenital malformation (morphologic abnormality)	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
abnormal tooth spacing nos	An abnormal opening or fissure between two adjacent teeth.
diastema of teeth (diagnosis)	An abnormal opening or fissure between two adjacent teeth.
congenital malformations (diagnosis)	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
ellis-van creveld syndrome	Dwarfism occurring in association with defective development of skin, hair, and teeth, polydactyly, and defect of the cardiac septum. (Dorland, 27th ed)
fetal alcohol syndrome	disorder occurring in children born to alcoholic women who continue to drink heavily during pregnancy; common abnormalities are growth deficiency (prenatal and postnatal), altered morphogenesis, mental deficiency, and characteristic facies - small eyes and flattened nasal bridge; fine motor dysfunction and tremulousness are observed in the newborn.
fragile x syndrome	A condition characterized genotypically by mutation of the distal end of the long arm of the X chromosome (at gene loci FRAXA or FRAXE) and phenotypically by cognitive impairment, hyperactivity, SEIZURES, language delay, and enlargement of the ears, head, and testes. INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY occurs in nearly all males and roughly 50% of females with the full mutation of FRAXA. (From Menkes, Textbook of Child Neurology, 5th ed, p226)
tooth; fusion	Two teeth united during development by the union of their tooth germs; the teeth may be joined by the enamel of their crowns, by their root dentin, or by both.
fusion; tooth	Two teeth united during development by the union of their tooth germs; the teeth may be joined by the enamel of their crowns, by their root dentin, or by both.
hallermann's syndrome	An oculomandibulofacial syndrome principally characterized by dyscephaly (usually brachycephaly), parrot nose, mandibular hypoplasia, proportionate nanism, hypotrichosis, bilateral congenital cataracts, and microphthalmia. (Dorland, 27th ed)
cavernous nevus of skin	A vascular anomaly that is a collection of tortuous BLOOD VESSELS and connective tissue. This tumor-like mass with the large vascular space is filled with blood and usually appears as a strawberry-like lesion in the subcutaneous areas of the face, extremities, or other regions of the body including the central nervous system.
strawberry hemangiomas	A vascular anomaly that is a collection of tortuous BLOOD VESSELS and connective tissue. This tumor-like mass with the large vascular space is filled with blood and usually appears as a strawberry-like lesion in the subcutaneous areas of the face, extremities, or other regions of the body including the central nervous system.
hutchinson teeth	An incisor with a half-moon shape incisal edge. []
hutchinson's teeth	An incisor with a half-moon shape incisal edge. []
congenital anomaly, nos	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
hypodontia	The absence of five or less teeth from the normal series by a failure to develop. [HPO:ibailleulforestier, PMID:31468724]
kartagener syndrome	An autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a triad of DEXTROCARDIA; INFERTILITY; and SINUSITIS. The syndrome is caused by mutations of DYNEIN genes encoding motility proteins which are components of sperm tails, and CILIA in the respiratory and the reproductive tracts.
fetal malformation	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
syndromes, angioosteohypertrophy	A congenital disorder that is characterized by a triad of capillary malformations (HEMANGIOMA), venous malformations (ARTERIOVENOUS FISTULA), and soft tissue or bony hypertrophy of the limb. This syndrome is caused by mutations in the VG5Q gene which encodes a strong angiogenesis stimulator.
syndrome, klippel-trenaunay	A congenital disorder that is characterized by a triad of capillary malformations (HEMANGIOMA), venous malformations (ARTERIOVENOUS FISTULA), and soft tissue or bony hypertrophy of the limb. This syndrome is caused by mutations in the VG5Q gene which encodes a strong angiogenesis stimulator.
klippel-trenaunay-weber syndrome	A congenital disorder that is characterized by a triad of capillary malformations (HEMANGIOMA), venous malformations (ARTERIOVENOUS FISTULA), and soft tissue or bony hypertrophy of the limb. This syndrome is caused by mutations in the VG5Q gene which encodes a strong angiogenesis stimulator.
trichorhinophalangeal syndrome ii	Autosomal dominant disorder characterized by cone-shaped epiphyses in the hands and multiple cartilaginous exostoses. INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY and abnormalities of chromosome 8 are often present. The exostoses in this syndrome appear identical to those of hereditary multiple exostoses (EXOSTOSES, HEREDITARY MULTIPLE).
acrodysplasia vs	Autosomal dominant disorder characterized by cone-shaped epiphyses in the hands and multiple cartilaginous exostoses. INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY and abnormalities of chromosome 8 are often present. The exostoses in this syndrome appear identical to those of hereditary multiple exostoses (EXOSTOSES, HEREDITARY MULTIPLE).
congenital abnormality nos	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
langer giedion syndrome	Autosomal dominant disorder characterized by cone-shaped epiphyses in the hands and multiple cartilaginous exostoses. INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY and abnormalities of chromosome 8 are often present. The exostoses in this syndrome appear identical to those of hereditary multiple exostoses (EXOSTOSES, HEREDITARY MULTIPLE).
laurence-moon syndrome	En autosomalt recessiv sjukdom som kännetecknas av hypogonadism, nedbrytning av ryggmärg och lillhjärna, psykisk funktionsnedsättning, retinitis pigmentosa och fetma. Syndromet kallades Laurence-Moon-Biedls syndrom tills Bardet-Biedls syndrom erkändes som ett självständigt sjukdomstillstånd.
macroglossias	The presence of an excessively large tongue, which may be congenital or may develop as a result of a tumor or edema due to obstruction of lymphatic vessels, or it may occur in association with hyperpituitarism or acromegaly. It also may be associated with malocclusion because of pressure of the tongue on the teeth. (From Jablonski, Dictionary of Dentistry, 1992)
deformities	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
macrostomia	Greatly exaggerated width of the mouth, resulting from failure of union of the maxillary and mandibular processes, with extension of the oral orifice toward the ear. The defect may be unilateral or bilateral. (Dorland, 27th ed)
hypoplasia of tongue	Decreased length and width of the tongue. [PMID:19125428]
microglossia	Decreased length and width of the tongue. [PMID:19125428]
small oral aperture	A congenital defect in which the mouth is unusually small. (Dorland, 27th ed)
congenital oral malformation	Congenital absence of or defects in structures of the mouth.
abnormalities, mouth	Congenital absence of or defects in structures of the mouth.
dystrophia myotonica	Neuromuscular disorder characterized by PROGRESSIVE MUSCULAR ATROPHY; MYOTONIA, and various multisystem atrophies. Mild INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY may also occur. Abnormal TRINUCLEOTIDE REPEAT EXPANSION in the 3' UNTRANSLATED REGIONS of DMPK PROTEIN gene is associated with Myotonic Dystrophy 1. DNA REPEAT EXPANSION of zinc finger protein-9 gene intron is associated with Myotonic Dystrophy 2.
fetal anomaly	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
teeth present at birth	Predeciduous teeth present at birth. They may be well formed and normal or may represent hornified epithelial structures without roots. They are found on the gingivae over the crest of the ridge and arise from accessory buds of the dental lamina ahead of the deciduous buds or from buds of the accessory dental lamina. (From Jablonski, Dictionary of Dentistry, 1992)
developmental malformation	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
familial turner syndrome	A genetically heterogeneous, multifaceted disorder characterized by short stature, webbed neck, ptosis, skeletal malformations, hypertelorism, hormonal imbalance, CRYPTORCHIDISM, multiple cardiac abnormalities (most commonly including PULMONARY VALVE STENOSIS), and some degree of INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY. The phenotype bears similarities to that of TURNER SYNDROME that occurs only in females and has its basis in a 45, X karyotype abnormality. Noonan syndrome occurs in both males and females with a normal karyotype (46,XX and 46,XY). Mutations in a several genes (PTPN11, KRAS, SOS1, NF1 and RAF1) have been associated the NS phenotype. Mutations in PTPN11 are the most common. LEOPARD SYNDROME, a disorder that has clinical features overlapping those of Noonan Syndrome, is also due to mutations in PTPN11. In addition, there is overlap with the syndrome called neurofibromatosis-Noonan syndrome due to mutations in NF1.
noonans syndrome	A genetically heterogeneous, multifaceted disorder characterized by short stature, webbed neck, ptosis, skeletal malformations, hypertelorism, hormonal imbalance, CRYPTORCHIDISM, multiple cardiac abnormalities (most commonly including PULMONARY VALVE STENOSIS), and some degree of INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY. The phenotype bears similarities to that of TURNER SYNDROME that occurs only in females and has its basis in a 45, X karyotype abnormality. Noonan syndrome occurs in both males and females with a normal karyotype (46,XX and 46,XY). Mutations in a several genes (PTPN11, KRAS, SOS1, NF1 and RAF1) have been associated the NS phenotype. Mutations in PTPN11 are the most common. LEOPARD SYNDROME, a disorder that has clinical features overlapping those of Noonan Syndrome, is also due to mutations in PTPN11. In addition, there is overlap with the syndrome called neurofibromatosis-Noonan syndrome due to mutations in NF1.
fetal anomaly (diagnosis)	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
renal oculocerebrodystrophy	A sex-linked recessive disorder affecting multiple systems including the EYE, the NERVOUS SYSTEM, and the KIDNEY. Clinical features include congenital CATARACT; MENTAL RETARDATION; and renal tubular dysfunction (FANCONI SYNDROME; RENAL TUBULAR ACIDOSIS; X-LINKED HYPOPHOSPHATEMIA or vitamin-D-resistant rickets) and SCOLIOSIS. This condition is due to a deficiency of phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate-5-phosphatase leading to defects in PHOSPHATIDYLINOSITOL metabolism and INOSITOL signaling pathway. (from Menkes, Textbook of Child Neurology, 5th ed, p60; Am J Hum Genet 1997 Jun;60(6):1384-8)
orodigitofacial dysostosis	Two syndromes of oral, facial, and digital malformations. Type I (Papillon-Leage and Psaume syndrome, Gorlin-Psaume syndrome) is inherited as an X-linked dominant trait and is found only in females and XXY males. Type II (Mohr syndrome) is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait.
oral-facial-digital syndrome	Two syndromes of oral, facial, and digital malformations. Type I (Papillon-Leage and Psaume syndrome, Gorlin-Psaume syndrome) is inherited as an X-linked dominant trait and is found only in females and XXY males. Type II (Mohr syndrome) is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait.
osteochondrodysplasia	Abnormal development of cartilage and bone.
papillon-lefevre syndrome	Rare, autosomal recessive disorder occurring between the first and fifth years of life. It is characterized by palmoplantar keratoderma with periodontitis followed by the premature shedding of both deciduous and permanent teeth. Mutations in the gene for CATHEPSIN C have been associated with this disease.
cyst, parovarian	A cyst (CYSTS) near the OVARY, derived from anomalies of the FALLOPIAN TUBES or the BROAD LIGAMENT. The paramesonephric type consists of ciliated cells similar to the oviduct epithelium. The mesonephric type consisted of an epithelium with minimally surface structures. They can be found on the thin oviduct (paratubal cysts) or near its fimbriated end (hydatid of Morgagni).
robin sequence (disorder)	Congenital malformation characterized by MICROGNATHIA or RETROGNATHIA; GLOSSOPTOSIS and CLEFT PALATE. The mandibular abnormalities often result in difficulties in sucking and swallowing. The syndrome may be isolated or associated with other syndromes (e.g., ANDERSEN SYNDROME; CAMPOMELIC DYSPLASIA). Developmental mis-expression of SOX9 TRANSCRIPTION FACTOR gene on chromosome 17q and its surrounding region is associated with the syndrome.
rothmund-thomson syndrome	Autosomalt recessivt syndrom som förekommer huvudsakligen hos kvinnor och kännetecknas av retikulära, atrofiska, hyperpigmenterade, telangiekta hudplack. Ackompanjeras ofta av juvenil katarakt, sadelnäsa, medfödda skelettdefekter, rubbningar i tillväxten av hår, naglar och tänder samt hypogonadism.
dysmorphisms	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
prader labhart willi syndrome	An autosomal dominant disorder caused by deletion of the proximal long arm of the paternal chromosome 15 (15q11-q13) or by inheritance of both of the pair of chromosomes 15 from the mother (UNIPARENTAL DISOMY) which are imprinted (GENETIC IMPRINTING) and hence silenced. Clinical manifestations include MENTAL RETARDATION; MUSCULAR HYPOTONIA; HYPERPHAGIA; OBESITY; short stature; HYPOGONADISM; STRABISMUS; and HYPERSOMNOLENCE. (Menkes, Textbook of Child Neurology, 5th ed, p229)
syndrome; abdominal muscle deficiency	A syndrome characterized by abdominal wall musculature deficiency, cryptorchism, and urinary tract abnormalities. The syndrome derives its name from its characteristic distended abdomen with wrinkled skin.
triad syndrome	A syndrome characterized by abdominal wall musculature deficiency, cryptorchism, and urinary tract abnormalities. The syndrome derives its name from its characteristic distended abdomen with wrinkled skin.
pseudohermaphroditism	condition in which the gonads are of one sex but one or more contradictions exist in the morphologic criteria of sex; female pseudohermaphroditism is a form in which the affected individual is a genetic and gonadal female with partial masculinization; male pseudohermaphroditism is a form in which the affected individual is a genetic and gonadal male with incomplete masculinization.
congenital respiratory tract malformation nos	Congenital structural abnormalities of the respiratory system.
system abnormalities, respiratory	Congenital structural abnormalities of the respiratory system.
rubenstein taybi syndrome	A chromosomal disorder characterized by MENTAL RETARDATION, broad thumbs, webbing of fingers and toes, beaked nose, short upper lip, pouting lower lip, agenesis of corpus callosum, large foramen magnum, keloid formation, pulmonary stenosis, vertebral anomalies, chest wall anomalies, sleep apnea, and megacolon. The disease has an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance and is associated with deletions of the short arm of chromosome 16 (16p13.3).
schwartz jampel syndrome	A classification for rare genetic syndromes with an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. Clinical features include muscle stiffness and weakness, facial and skeletal abnormalities with joint contractures and short stature. Two types have been characterized: Schwartz-Jampel Syndrome type I (SJSI) and Schwartz-Jampel Syndrome type II (SJSII). SJSI is associated with a mutation of the HSPG2 gene on chromosome 1 and has been further characterized into two subtypes IA and IB. SJSIA is more common, less severe in presentation and is seen later in childhood than SJSIB. For both SJSI subtypes, prognosis is favorable as the main feature of muscle stiffness is slowly progressive, if at all, and is compatible with a normal life span. SJSII is apparent at birth, shares the same clinical profile and mutation in the LIFR gene noted in Stuve-Wiedemann Syndrome and is thus presumed to be the same disorder. In contrast to SJSI, its presentation is more severe and likelihood of survivability is much lower.
sympodia	A disorder characterized by the malformation of the legs into a single lower limb.
fused legs and feet	A disorder characterized by the malformation of the legs into a single lower limb.
sirenomelia	A disorder characterized by the malformation of the legs into a single lower limb.
fatty alcohol:nad+ oxidoreductase deficiency	An autosomal recessive neurocutaneous disorder characterized by severe ichthyosis MENTAL RETARDATION; SPASTIC PARAPLEGIA; and congenital ICHTHYOSIS. It is caused by mutation of gene encoding microsomal fatty ALDEHYDE DEHYDROGENASE leading to defect in fatty alcohol metabolism.
sturge syndrome weber	A non-inherited congenital condition with vascular and neurological abnormalities. It is characterized by facial vascular nevi (PORT-WINE STAIN), and capillary angiomatosis of intracranial membranes (MENINGES; CHOROID). Neurological features include EPILEPSY; cognitive deficits; GLAUCOMA; and visual defects.
weber syndrome	A non-inherited congenital condition with vascular and neurological abnormalities. It is characterized by facial vascular nevi (PORT-WINE STAIN), and capillary angiomatosis of intracranial membranes (MENINGES; CHOROID). Neurological features include EPILEPSY; cognitive deficits; GLAUCOMA; and visual defects.
milles' syndrome	A non-inherited congenital condition with vascular and neurological abnormalities. It is characterized by facial vascular nevi (PORT-WINE STAIN), and capillary angiomatosis of intracranial membranes (MENINGES; CHOROID). Neurological features include EPILEPSY; cognitive deficits; GLAUCOMA; and visual defects.
cm - congenital malformation	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
fallots tetralogy	A combination of congenital heart defects consisting of four key features including VENTRICULAR SEPTAL DEFECTS; PULMONARY STENOSIS; RIGHT VENTRICULAR HYPERTROPHY; and a dextro-positioned AORTA. In this condition, blood from both ventricles (oxygen-rich and oxygen-poor) is pumped into the body often causing CYANOSIS.
congenital defect, nos	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
tetralogy, fallots	A combination of congenital heart defects consisting of four key features including VENTRICULAR SEPTAL DEFECTS; PULMONARY STENOSIS; RIGHT VENTRICULAR HYPERTROPHY; and a dextro-positioned AORTA. In this condition, blood from both ventricles (oxygen-rich and oxygen-poor) is pumped into the body often causing CYANOSIS.
tetralogy of fallot	A combination of congenital heart defects consisting of four key features including VENTRICULAR SEPTAL DEFECTS; PULMONARY STENOSIS; RIGHT VENTRICULAR HYPERTROPHY; and a dextro-positioned AORTA. In this condition, blood from both ventricles (oxygen-rich and oxygen-poor) is pumped into the body often causing CYANOSIS.
thanatophoric dysplasia	A severe form of neonatal dwarfism with very short limbs. All cases have died at birth or later in the neonatal period.
malformation of teeth	Congenital absence of or defects in structures of the teeth.
defects congen	Malformations of organs or body parts during development in utero.
tooth abnormalities	Congenital absence of or defects in structures of the teeth.
crowded teeth	The condition when the summation of the mesio distal width of the teeth is larger than the arch perimeter.
dental crowding	The condition when the summation of the mesio distal width of the teeth is larger than the arch perimeter.
impacted tooth	A tooth that is prevented from erupting by a physical barrier, usually other teeth. Impaction may also result from orientation of the tooth in an other than vertical position in the periodontal structures.
